151303624.review:
Many people might think this game is unfair, that lots of deaths are unavoidable. But most of the time that's not the case, and there was some decision that would have allowed you to survive. A lot of skill in rain world is about smart preemptive decision making, and if you analyze your deaths for what you can improve on, you can learn the game.

Something I love about this game is that lots of interactions and the lore are more realistic than you would expect of a game. It really feels like this is a real world.

For most people, I would recommend playing with the rain world remix sort of built in mod, and the tips system enabled. It teaches you a lot of the fundamentals one at a time as you play, but even with that you still need to be compassionate and observant in order to have a smooth experience, and that's part of the appeal of the game.

Basically, this game isn't for everyone, but if you're looking for a game that challenges you to master its tricks rather than just stumbling through, I highly recommend it.

151277472.review:
Rain World is hands down the coolest story-packed survival and exploration game I've ever played. You can pretty much go anywhere and do anything, and the best part is, there's this awesome story that unfolds as you go. It feels crazy satisfying when everything comes together in the end.

When it comes to the music, It's a game-changer, especially the tracks that kick in when danger's lurking. It's like a musical heads-up to be on your toes. Each region even has its own danger soundtrack, adding a whole vibe to the atmosphere.

Rain World doesn't hold your hand much (mostly just in the beginning in my experience), so figuring out where to go will make you scratch your head, it may even feel frustrating sometimes. I've ended up wandering aimlessly a bunch. But weirdly, it's made me learn the layout of the game way better. I've even resorted to checking out maps on wiki pages to get the hang of where to go.

Then there's Downpour, the expansion that has only increased my love for the game. It continues to undfold and reveal more about the lore, giving you a way better understanding of the characters and the whole ecosystem. Rain World, with its mix of freedom, challenge, and stories, isn't just a game—it's a wild ride that's made my gaming world a whole lot richer.

Rain World isn't for the faint of heart due to its steep learning curve, but, if you're up for a challenge I implore you to play the game and take your time getting the under-hang of it.

151060615.review:
I usually hate survival games, but Rain World manages to stand out from the rest and be an incredible experience. This is definitely one of my favorite games of all time, and I'm doubtful anything similar will ever top it. If you're thinking about getting this game, note that the Downpour DLC is a must-have; the base game is great, but the DLC has more content than the game itself and is what makes it so phenomenal.

PROS:

Simplicity - Unlike most survival games, there's no inventory or crafting system. What you're carrying in your two hands is what you get. The only thing you have to manage is eating enough food between rain cycles so that you can hibernate. There's a lot of versatility and subtlety in using the items you collect, which you gradually pick up on as you play.

Enemy Design - The best thing about the game is the complex ecosystem, where enemies interact with the player and with each-other in simple yet complicated and unpredictable ways. Even the basic lizard enemy that you first encounter has a lot of depth to it's behavior; it will chase you, sure, but will often get distracted fighting with other lizards, giving you a much easier time sneaking by. There's too much to talk about here, but enemy AI has never been better in any other game.

Music - The music of Rain World is fantastic.

Story-Telling - Rain World has a unique and compelling plot, and does a better job with atmospheric story-telling than any other game I've played. This is increased a hundredfold by the Downpour DLC. 

Exploration - The Rain World map is absolutely gigantic; even after 80 hours of playing, there's still an entire area I've left practically unexplored.

CONS:

Difficulty - Rain World leaves the player to stumble around in the dark. Learning how to deal with all the hostile creatures takes a lot of patience, and dying can be extremely punishing. This isn't a bad thing for me personally, but I don't think this game is for everyone.

No Direction - Rain World gives the player very little instruction on where to go or how to progress, and you can spend hours exploring areas without feeling like you've gotten any farther in the game. This caused me to quit the game early on, eventually coming back to it and restarting. This isn't really a bad thing either, because it makes certain moments of the game much more powerful when you finally get to them, but if you're looking for a game to give you instruction on what to do, you won't find it playing Rain World.

150871201.review:
Rain World does an excellent job of making you feel like a part of a living, breathing ecosystem. You aren't necessarily at the top of the food chain in this world, and you certainly begin to feel that after the first twenty or so times you get eaten by something much larger than you.

This game has an rather large world to explore and a story to learn about if you look for it. Each playable character (save for Monk and Survivor mostly) are unique in their abilities and campaigns, allowing for unique experiences depending on the character you select.
There are also a handful of collectables placed around the world, giving an incentive to venture out into the far reaches of each region you come across. Finding these collectables allows you to access more items in the sandbox and arena modes the game features, where you can spawn in the various creatures and items in the game to play around with at your own pace. 
In the Downpour DLC, there are also custom-built challenges created for each playable character, along with an "Expedition" gamemode, which has you embark on short journeys in the game world while completing randomly generated challenges for points. 
All these sandbox gamemodes and the story mode itself give the game a great deal of replay value.

Something to keep in mind: Rain World is a challenging game. You will likely spend a lot of time getting lost and dying in the first few hours of gameplay as you learn of the game's systems and controls. 

If you can get past the harsh learning experience that is the first few hours, you are in for a truly special experience with a unique art style, an immersive interconnected open world, and a great soundtrack to boot. Rain World is definitely one of my favorite games of all time, and I would highly recommend giving it a try if the game seems even remotely interesting to you.

150492703.review:
Very bizarre, tough and interesting game with awesome movement mechanics and interesting enemy behaviors. The procedural animation, simulation and amount of details in this game are awe inspiring, but there are some questionable level and game design decisions that can ruin the experience. Spoilers ahead!

-- SPOILERS --

1. Shaded Citadel aka not being able to see anything = challenge?
While this location is somewhat optional, when you finally get the hang of the game and start to enjoy it, you get to an area called The Shaded Citadel, in which you simply can't see anything but your character. I'm not sure why the developers of this game thought making everything literally pitch-black fun game design. Yes, I know you can trade or hunt scavengers for lanterns, kidnap light rats or play monk, but it still doesn't justify this decision. This place is hell and I'd rather stick my head in the toilet than go through it ever again. The light rats are cute though.

2. Lack of guidance - this is an "immersion first" type of game...
Yes, it's fun to explore and figure things out. But why can't the game clearly explain itself once in a while? The Karma system is not intuitive, the symbols should be numbers instead, the little dots that represent the current cycle are confusing at first, the fact that you can store items, swap items, etc is not taught to the player. The game will guide you with the face of a robot, and you should somehow know that this is where you need to go because robot face equals progression. There are many other issues with the UI being unintuitive and filled with unexplained symbols.
To sum it up, it seems like the game prefers immersion to gameplay.

3. Lack of Direction / Motivation / Hooks
No, I'm not speaking about knowing where to go, because those guide-ghosts do kind of show you the way. I'm talking about something that will keep you going. That will make you want to go on. A hook that gets you involved in the game. It starts with one, but fails to lure you further in. The only reason I kept going is because downpour released and I could finally play the campaign with my friends, which is a far superior experience to playing alone.
This game should be treated more like a sandbox/simulator than a journey, even though it sets you on a journey.

4. Gates
I kind of get the point, but they involve too much guesswork and luck and the symbols look too similar. The game loves to gatekeep you, and combined with its unpredictable nature, this can result in extremely frustrating moments. For example, you finally reach that gate after many attempts to progress, but oh poor you, you are one hibernation away from entering, go back to find a den. And when you do find one, you're almost there but a random lizard emerges out of nowhere and grabs you. Now you are two hibernations away. This is ok every once in a while, but the game does this systematically. Let the difficulty of the game gatekeep you instead... It's already a tough game as it is. In my opinion, gate-locks should be removed from the game or revamped. Maybe there's an option in the new update that I missed though.


--- TLDR ---

All in all this is a good game and I've had lots of fun with it, but I've definitely had my "what the hell" moments, and there are many questionable level-deisgn scenarios and UI related issues. Other than that, there is a pitch-black area which is extremely unfun and too difficult to progress, and the game (which is hard enough as it is) is filled with gates that require special conditions to open and they mostly provide more frustration.

150480579.review:
This is Rainworld.

You are playing a slugcat, very cute little creature living in the world that is rather cruel. The world is immersive from the moment you start the game washed up divided appart from your family unknowing about the area you are in.

The controls might be unituitive at first and you will struggle. Oh you will struggle so much that you will wonder if you ever even have known if you learnt how to jump, grab or use items, but the longer you play the more you master this game. The magic is that you won't lose the challenging part of it.

There are still danger noodles everywhere and even if you learn how to dodge or kill them you never know what they will do thank to the great Ai, dangerous at the best and..... funny at the worst. (Seriously blue spinny lizards are such mood) 

There is still a lot to learn, only the movement guide that you can find on the internet is over 50 pages long, but you don't need to learn all of those to play and finish this game (Even though it could help)

The pixelart has its charm, for some coudl appear ugly at first, but it has such beauty with background and areas that you will stand and try to take the view (if you aren't chased by even more danger noodled and danger noodle deluxe edition with added wings and maybe even the animal equivalent of a shooting gun) You will learn to love the tiny slugcat body and its tiny eyes.

The lore is there for those who want and the base game carries short and interesting story. 

I can't recommend this game enough. If you like to play games not to finish it or for the progress (Because you will die and you will die a lot)  and are playing games for rather challenging experience I would give this game a shot.

Though I already have to recommend buying DLC with it because the DLC is so worth it.

+ Slugcat is adorable

Feels like you are actually a ferret, and I love that so much! The way you move is so realistic, despite being a fictional slugcat. The ecosystem is so natural and intriguing, with surprises everywhere. The creatures move according to the rules of nature, and rarely, but still, even so, you can actually escape from them. Even if caught, if you struggle correctly, you can escape, and I love that realism as a prey animal in this game. You can even get predators to chase after you, goading them by getting up in their space or positioning yourself in an easy to escape position (more or less... I've failed on more than one occasion). Why would you want predators to chase you if they are already after you? Well sometimes, like many predators, they don't actually want to eat you just yet, but well, there is a big ambush predator in your way, and you don't want to be the one eaten. So lure that predator in, and have them fight. Let's you and him fight. There are multiple ways to achieve objectives, and you can even set up long-term plans. And don't even get me started on the absolutely wonderful mechanic of the rainstorms. 
I genuinely, completely seriously, wholly and fully say this game gives me a reason to live life.

150241182.review:
Its difficulty leads you to frequently and subconsciously take moments to appreciate not being dead. During these moments, your focus broadens, and you see the world around you. Details in the cobbled stone you walk realize themselves, and the lives of all those who have ever trodden it and ever will manifest in your attention. You've worked so hard to get here-- was it worth it? Does that question even mean anything, considering here isn't anywhere special at all and an experience being worth anything is a ridiculous concept anyways?

The experience of Rain World is deeply allegorical. 

Sometimes a blow is too much, a failure too humiliating, that you make that judgement call. Its not worth it anymore. You try in vain for any glimpse of the goal that you assume is out there, but all you see is overcast skies and empty black tunnels. There is no guide, there are no rails, so for all you know the path you're treading leads nowhere at all.

Succeeding in Rain World requires you to realize a new perspective on the worth of experience.

In these moments, these moments of reflection, of peace, where the music swells for nothing, nowhere, nobody at all, you realize just how worth it it was.

I gave this game a fair shot, alternating between Monk and Survivor.  I'm done with it - here's why:

- Poor platforming: crouch jumps will only work about half of the time, with no rhyme or reason.  Jumping between adjacent walls to go up - also only randomly effective.  And when trying to climb a ladder? This is the only game I've seen where the character gets hung up on the sides of the ladder!  Awful stuff.
- No scrolling: An unforgivable design choice in an unforgiving game.  This could prevent so many accidental deaths of walking into an enemy simply because it is one screen over.  
- Inconsistency: You won't die if you and an enemy are going through the same 'dashed line' pipe.  You will die if you are going through the same 'sideless' pipe.  Why? I don't know.

I know many of you out there love this game. I don't.

150129700.review:
Absolutely fantastic game.

TLDR: game is very good but very hard (particularly to begin with)

Rain world has one of the most incredible and dynamic ecosystems in any game, the AI is simple code wise and yet unmatched (even with a couple of less favourable examples) in its overall interconnecting realism and complexity. the game really is an ecosystem on its own that you are just living in.

The combat is brilliantly handled, with the player being one effectively one shot to anything yet able to dish out some violence in return. This is an ecosystem and you are at the bottom of the food chain.

The DLC is massive and like a whole game with the amount of content it adds, definitely get that with the base game if you like rain world sounds.

The lore is fascinating and intricate although you will likely only see the surface in the average run.

The difficulty is a turn off for many people and if you struggle with hard games you may not like it. Although the feeling of reward when you do eventually learn the game  is amazing. People complain about the RNG which is somewhat fair but since its basically an ecosystem simulator on top of a game it should be expected, you cant anticipate what another animal should do so the game doesn't let you.

The art style if beautiful, sound/music is great and used sparingly keeping it fresh and maintaining the perfect atmosphere and level design is phenomenal (although not quite perfect) the stages are designed around parkour combat and exploration with easier but longer roots for less daring players and run around to avoid the ecosystem doing its thing and blocking your path from one way. 

Personally ive never had an issue with reindeer yet but from what ive heard and seen they are quite buggy but not as big a deal as people make them out to be.

Overall this game is a rewarding, skilful and unique; definitely give it a try. not necessary the right game for the plebs who struggle to play hard games.

150054977.review:
[h3]Rain World: a Game that creates its own Experience[/h3]
     There are plenty of games out there that are fun. There are plenty that are visually breathtaking or challenge players’ skills. But it is only the very best ones that create their own entire experience. Rain World, is an excellent example of this. Despite receiving mixed reviews from critics, it achieves this unique experience with a vast, interesting world, lots of mechanical depth, and an incredibly immersive atmosphere.

     In Rain World, the player plays as a "slugcat," an aptly named creature that seems to resemble both a slug and a cat. The player jumps, crawls, hides, gathers food, and hunts in a vast, two dimensional world, exploring every unique corner of a diverse ecosystem on an alien planet, all while avoiding a frequent, deadly downpour. This world contains all sorts of odd, sometimes seemingly impossible creatures, which interact not only with the player but with each other inside of an elaborate, simulated ecosystem, in which the player is but a small part of. However, slugcats sit rather low on the food chain in this ecosystem, and often find themselves being hunted by terrifying, ravenous predators. The player must quickly learn to survive in this world by gathering enough food, avoiding predators, and most importantly, not getting caught in the rain.

	One of the things that makes Rain World unique is the natural way that it lets players learn. Instead of shoving wordy tutorial messages in the player’s face or starting out with lengthy and obnoxiously easy challenges, Rain World throws the player straight into the deep end of the pool, and leaves them to learn how to swim on their own. At the beginning of the game, it shows the player the basic controls and other fundamental mechanics of the game, but then immediately sets the player free to explore. The player will probably die countless times throughout their journey, but every time they do they can use that experience to survive the next time they are in a similar situation. While playing this game, the player really feels like they are learning to survive on their own in an unfamiliar world using tricks, exploits, and strategies that they come up with completely on their own. For example, after getting eaten by a ferocious lizard the first couple of times, the player might eventually notice that the lizards are not capable of climbing poles. They can then use this knowledge to easily stay well away from the jaws of the beast, and live for another day. This kind of process happens frequently across all kinds of different situations throughout the entire game.

	Another reason Rain World is so interesting is because of the incredibly in-depth ecosystem that it simulates. Every single creature the player encounters in this game has its own survival in mind, its own encounters with other creatures, and sometimes even a unique personality. Unlike other games where everything revolves around the player, the player is only a small part of this vast ecosystem. To demonstrate that the player is really not the main character of this universe, a lizard which has caught the player might get distracted by another lizard, which it decides to fight over territory with, losing interest in the player. Additionally, the game keeps track of and simulates all of the creatures in a wide area, allowing all kinds of interactions amongst the wildlife to happen constantly regardless of whether or not they are being observed by the player. This results in the player often walking into situations happening between other creatures that they aren’t even involved in, which helps make the world seem so much more lively. 

	The AI’s of the creatures in this game are also quite realistic. Lizards hunting for food will wander around, investigating small noises they hear, and give chase only when they spot something with their limited vision. Giant Vultures will swoop down upon unsuspecting prey, only to fly off frustrated when their prey hides out of reach. The most notable example of this game’s intricate AI systems are the Scavengers, which are monkey-like creatures that live in tribes across the map. Individual Scavengers have unique personalities, remember the player’s actions with a reputation system, demonstrate emotion, and even communicate with the player using body language.  These kinds of deep systems and mechanics not only breathe more life into the game, but also keep the game feeling fresh later on, since it gives the player more advanced systems to learn about and use to their advantage.

	One of the greatest things about Rain World is the incredible sense of atmosphere it creates. From the soft sound of dripping water after a fresh rain cycle to the faint chirping of small insects in the background to the distant whirring of ancient machines, there are so many small details in the world’s ambient sound design that makes players feel like they are really in the world themselves. There are also many visual elements, such as colorful rainbows, foggy landscapes in the background, or cascading shadows cast from clouds rolling by, that further contribute to allowing the player to become immersed in the world. 

	Adding to the atmosphere is the game’s music, or lack thereof. The player will spend much of their time accompanied by no music at all, creating a lonely and sometimes unsettling feeling. But, during key moments of the game, various types of songs do play, like the hollow, lonely song that plays when you first open the game, the percussive and suspenseful music that plays when in danger, or the ominous, ancient hymns that play at mysterious locations. Perhaps the most important aspect of the atmosphere, however, is the game’s story and the player’s journey itself. The game’s story is a tragic tale about the protagonist slugcat being separated from their family at a young age, losing all hope of returning, and searching for a new purpose. This story is reflected quite well in the game’s depressing, lonely, and desperate atmosphere.

	However, Rain World is certainly not flawless. One common criticism of the game is that controlling the slugcat feels rather “sluggish” and imprecise. While this may feel like the case at first, it really just takes some practice. After spending enough time learning and mastering the controls, it starts to make sense, and players are able to move more deliberately, with precision, and much more swiftly. Some people also don’t like the lack of guidance and the openness of the game, which admittedly does sometimes lead to new players winding up stuck in extremely difficult sections of the game they weren’t intended to be in yet. This is certainly an issue, but the game does use multiple methods that attempt to subtly steer the player back on track, so these cases are somewhat rare. Finally, the main issue that many people have with this game is with the sheer difficulty, and how cruel and punishing this game can sometimes be. When playing through the game for the first time, many players will find the game overly difficult and frustrating, not enjoying this type of extreme challenge at all. But this is simply just how the game is. While some are willing to push through the steep learning curve to experience the joy of mastering this game, most are, understandably, not.

	Despite its flaws, Rain World’s unique, immersive style of gameplay and story create not just a game, but an incredible, unique experience for some people, a journey which will be looked back upon fondly. However, its harsh and cruel nature will make it less than enjoyable for everyone else. So, while Rain World is certainly not a game for everyone, it is an incredible experience that is worth every minute of its time for those it does resonate with.

En términos de Thomas L. Thompson,1​ es la cuestión de su "aceptabilidad como historia".2​ Puede extenderse tanto a la Biblia hebrea (Antiguo Testamento) como al Nuevo Testamento cristiano (cuestiones del Jesús histórico y la era apostólica).

Entre los muchos campos de estudio utilizados para dilucidar la cuestión están la historia de las religiones (historia del judaísmo, historia del cristianismo), la arqueología (arqueología bíblica), la cronología (cronología bíblica), la astronomía, la lingüística (lenguas orientales bíblicas, lengua griega), la literatura comparada, etc. Los eruditos en estudios bíblicos examinan el contexto histórico del texto bíblico, la atribución de autoría de cada uno de los libros y el contraste entre la narración bíblica y las evidencias externas.

Los descubrimientos arqueológicos en ámbito bíblico3​ de los siglos XIX y XX han sido ambivalentes: mientras que unos parecen confirmar la narrativa del Antiguo Testamento, otros la ponen en cuestión.

You are a slugcat.
Slugcat is not a hero.
Slugcat is a animal, prey and predator.
No enemies, only animals, and you are not the only prey. They learn and grow. Be nice to them and you might even tame or befriend even the fiercest beasts.
No magic powerups, way to become stronger is learning the surprisingly complex movement techs and the weakness of each animal.
There is a story, follow the where the little yellow camera points. You might need to sleep to get more "karma" so doors open. Greet the remains of a ancient civilization. Don't eat the glowies on the beach. Check what the yellow friend shows you in pictures. You can help. Or leave.
DLC has more content than base game. Better endings for the base 2 slugcats. Many more slugcats with special behaviours set on different ages of the strange world. 
Become a slugcat. NOW.

149905773.review:
Don't play blind. I straight up don't recommend this game to you if you aren't planning to look things up or discuss the game with friends who know about it. The game has a tiny tutorial and complicated movement mechanics so feel free to look things up and DO NOT feel bad about it. The Rainworld Wiki is great for at least getting a basic idea of what locations to go next and what items do (and what controls to use them). 

If you play blind, you'll may get frustrated by how unfair the game is (it is unfair, the developers were more focused on simulating an ecosystem than making a balanced game) and you won't know where to go to progress, let alone how to use items like spore puffs or grappling worms.

Another thing: you can get mods and still get achievements, so you can play the game with all the QOL you want and not get punished (like SBCameraScroll if you want the camera to follow you). Alternatively, you can download Rotund World and become morbidly a beast.
 
Multiplayer is fun.
Slugpups are great.

149599935.review:
This game has a lot of reviews from users with hundreds of hours that say you should go in blind. It'll be frustrating and you'll ragequit, but as long as you keep coming back, eventually the game will click. Maybe it'll happen after fifty hours, maybe after a hundred, maybe two hundred, but eventually it'll click. The game also has story-based achievements, and only 13% of users have the achievement you get for reaching the half-way point. That's because most people never reach that second stage. I went in blind as the reviews said, got frustrated and ragequit as they predicted, but frankly I don't have the time to spend dozens if not hundreds of hours just to figure out the basic mechanics through trial and error, so I went ahead and read some of the articles on the wiki. I'm glad I did. I went back to the game after reading the wiki, had a great time and beat it, and I want to do a second playthrough later.

The frustration that comes with playing Rain World is twofold. The first reason for it is mechanical. It's a tough platformer. You die constantly, and a lot of the deaths are to RNG. However the second and more important reason is that the game is deliberately obscure. It tells you (almost) nothing. It doesn't even tell you you have a [spoiler]health bar[/spoiler]. When you start a new game, it doesn't tell you that "monk" is [spoiler]easy mode[/spoiler] and "surivor" is [spoiler]normal[/spoiler]. It doesn't tell you what moves you can do or how many items are edible. I'm sure it's mind-blowing playing this game for dozens of hours and then realizing you have a [spoiler]slide move[/spoiler], but I'd rather be told this information up front. The game is hard enough without requiring you to guess basic mechanics.

Once you have the basic gameplay information, Rain World turns into something more like a conventional metroidvania. You can go anywhere and gain access to new areas by picking up helpful items. You can lose those items again, but you need to bring a light if you're going into a dark area, things like that, so some routes through the game world are impractical. It's not a typical metroidvania for sure, but once you actually understand the mechanics, the game turns out to be much less strange than it seems at first. You jump on platforms, you fend off enemies, pick up health. You go from point A to point B to C, then the credits roll. The game world simulates an ecology, which is neat, but from the player's perspective it's only the deliberate obscuring of the mechanics that prevents you from playing it like (mostly) any other tough platformer with realistic-ish physics.

If you already know you're one of those <13% of players who don't mind ragequitting, coming back, ragequitting, coming back, etc., for dozens or hundreds of hours before you get it, by all means try it blind. If you're more like me, I'd really recommend reading the wiki before you ragequit and uninstall. You don't have to read any story spoilers, they all have big warning labels on them. Just read the page on the controls and some basic stuff like how hibernation and feeding work. My own frustration (mostly) went away at that point. I still died all the time, but now I didn't mind so much because I understood why.

The game looks great. I kept thinking of the game Another World in terms of the esthetics. It sounds great too, all moody background noise and drones with some minimalist music here and there. The atmosphere in general is spot-on. The enemy designs are cool and otherworldly. The world-building is consistent and well-done. The game even makes you feel for the couple of NPCs you come across. I played with a PS4 controller, which worked fine most of the time, but I found it very difficult to get the timing down on extended sections of wall-jumping, so I had to switch over to keyboard for these parts. On keyboard it was no problem. You can switch back and forth seamlessly between controller and keyboard, so you don't have to commit when you start. I played on Proton, and it seemed to run really well.

149518137.review:
This. F**king. Game.

I can comfortably say that beating Rain World is one of my most prized accomplishments when it comes to gaming. Not only because it's very difficult in a refreshingly unique way - more on that later - but also because the [i]spiritual significance[/i] of the game, the ending in particular, left an ever-aching scar on my heart that refuses to heal even years later.

There's this general belief that game journalists suck at games; I don't want to get into that right now, but I honestly believe that Rain World simply blindsided a lot of its more mainstream reviewers with its unconventional control scheme and strange, dynamic difficulty. This isn't a 2D platformer. The slugcat cannot really jump like we're used to; instead, it has a handy set of other movement abilities, and learning them in spite of your instincts is required to get anywhere.

And this is on top of the other unusual design choices. The world is incredibly interconnected and if you're persistent enough, there's nothing really preventing you from doing stuff out of order and even skipping a lot of the game. No worries though - the chances of you doing that on accident are very low.

What really makes Rain World shine, however, is the way its difficulty works. Almost all hard games can be learned, and that's what you're expected to do. Learn the steps and execute the dance. But Rain World shuffles things up every time you die. Enemies appear in different locations. A route you took last time might be inaccessible this time around due to a bunch of lizards fighting for turf. Sure, you could try sneaking past. Or even fighting them. But as a general rule you're not a fighter; you have to use a mixture of trickery, stealth, being quick on your feet and occasional violence to get by.

In other words, you're squarely in the lower half of the food chain. Yes, there are creatures that are below you that you can hunt and consume, but most things want to make a snack of you instead. And they will. Oh yes, they will.

The most memorable and glorious moments of the game will be where you will have barely escaped with your life over and over again in a single cycle and miraculously managed to find shelter just before the rain came. And as you start to really understand the workings of the world and the abilities of your slugcat, moments such as those will come more and more often. That's its true power.

On top of all that, Rain World has a spiritual component - one that is not immediately clear, but as you keep playing, you'll begin the true significance of a lot of stuff. I don't think it's practical to completely unravel the plot by yourself due to the insane things you need to do to get some pieces of info, though; I had to consult the wiki to really understand. But it's fine - you'll still get a very satisfying and emotional experience if you go only with what you can find by yourself.

And above all else - it's a very, very unique game, even by indie standards. Difficult, yes. But possible to learn and to master. Complex. Obtuse, perhaps; but so incredibly satisfying. Not for everyone, for sure - and yet, I implore you to check it out. I'm incredibly grateful to the Universe that I did and refused to give up.

149476262.review: Un juego hermoso y hecho con cariño para estresarte. Rain World tiene un sobresaliente apartado artístico y de físicas, estas últimas son geniales y le dan mucha esencia al juego. Sin embargo, su aleatoria aparición de criaturas en situaciones y posiciones determinadas generan casos en los que por ejemplo, nada más salir de un conducto o cambiar de escenario estés en la boca de un lagarto o tengas a uno de esos pájaros encima. En estas situaciones, es completamente imposible sobrevivir, no es que te falte habilidad, simplemente mala suerte y para suerte juguemos al poker, porque un juego cuyo sistema pueda hacer que simplemente mueras porque toca no debería existir. Entiendo que se quiera ofrecer un desafío pero fijémonos en un Dark Souls, es muy exigente y castiga un mínimo fallo con la muerte casi igual que este juego, la diferencia es que si has muerto en Dark Souls, es porque no fuiste suficientemente perfecto, no por falta de suerte. Sinceramente patético. Además añadir que hay obstáculos en el escenario innecesariamente difíciles de superar y esto más que un reto es un agobio y una sensación de estrés difícil de explicar. Como a ejemplo, pongo esas estructuras que parecen escaleras de mano. Por alguna razón, en Rain World al pasar de estar colgado a subir en una barra, el personaje se desplaza hacia la derecha y esto suele ocasionar que se agarre del barrote lateral en lugar de poder saltar hacia arriba y agarrarse a la siguiente barra horizontal. Lo resalto porque no os podéis imaginar lo desesperante que es estar media hora para subir. El 70% de este juego se puede considerar perder el tiempo: esperando a que se abran las puertas, durmiendo, muriendo injustamente y pasando ratos intentando subir una estúpida escalera o intentando que tu lanza sea lanzada hacia la dirección que quieres. El otro 30% se basa en aprender cosas sobre las criaturas y objetos que encuentras y explorando para buscar comida o el siguiente punto de control. En conclusión Rain World es casi un juego injustamente echo para desesperarte y en su mayor parte sientes que pierdes el tiempo, por otra parte tiene un excelente estilo artístico y sonoro, las criaturas son interesantes al igual que la historia que se pueda estar detrás del mundo, tiene un excelente decorado de escenarios, los movimientos se sienten muy orgánicos y por último recalcar que es un juego muy original y con mucha personalidad. A pesar de lo bueno, no puedo recomendar este juego a los jugadores en general.

149379556.review:
i just finished 100%ing rainworld. all challenges, all expeditions, every achievement. granted, i didnt finish the collection and i never did apex predator, both of which i fully intend to come back to in due time. this game... is truly something special. worth every moment, in spite of the dozens of silly and sometimes devastating deaths i took. the movement tech is delightful, the lore and the story being told are deeply spiritual and profound, i care about every character presented to me even though most of them never utter a word. i love this game. i played an hour and a half 2 years ago and dropped it until a few months ago, and i think about it a lot. once you have that breakthrough, this game becomes something irresistably challenging and exciting. it is so special to me. it might be my new favorite game ever made. if you want to be tested, if you want an uphill battle and to fight for your fucking life at all turns, if you want the fulfillment of overcoming it all. buy the game and the dlc. downpour is worth every penny. if its too much, just buy the base game and experience the initial story through monk. it is worth seeing. 

to my fellow completionists, this one is a fucking DOOZY and i don't immediately recommend doing what i did if you're a more casual enjoyer. challenge 70 caused me real actual impactful stress and put me in a bad mood for like 3 straight days. I nearly lost more than 1 500+ point expeditions and it had my heart pounding. this game is HARD. and it is BRUTAL in the ways it kills you. getting frame 1-ed by a scav or getting snagged by a lizard on a screen seam sucks!! but persevere and GOD the game rewards you! its such a fulfilling journey. stay strong.

149287258.review:
I can't fully describe how great of a game this is. It is an experience that I am glad I decided to take part it. The beautifully crafted landscapes, the surprisingly in depth movement system, the music that I can't ever seem to get enough off and the unforgiving yet satisfying reward of dominating the food chain. It's great.

This game is by no means easy, it shows you the bare minimum at the start and pretty much expects you to learn everything about the ecosystem that you are now suddenly part of and you will undoubtedly become a lizards lunch a good amount of times. You will likely end up feeling very lost at the start too, you aren't given a clear objective of where to go apart from a Yellow Overseer following you around pointing out various things about the environment you are in which at times can seemingly make you go back from where you just came. Because of this you can quite easily end up in a very difficult area which is honestly something that could be improved slightly to dissuade inexperienced players or at least give an idea of what to expect before essentially soft locking themselves. If I was to give any advice to new players for a slightly more enjoyable experience, head up and right at the start of the game.

The creatures of Rain World are often brought up in discussion as the way everything interacts creates a world that feels very real. One experience with a certain creature may differ greatly from each individual making you uncertain if you can repeat the same strategy on it for an easy victory. For example the Green Lizards, you may find one that is very lazy almost making no attempt at catching you, simply biting the air in your general direction when you are close. On the flip side you may get one that doesn't seem to give up chase and lunges at you much more motivated to get it's next meal. You can never quite be sure. (Can't say the same for Reds, They want you dead.)

I would talk about the scavs but honestly they have such a complex system that I don't think I can even begin to explain how real they feel at times. (minus the questionable reaction times that will never feel fair.) All I will say about them is try not to give them a reason to kill you.

I could honestly go on about how much I love about this game for ages. It's one of the games that I plan to eventually 100% (not doing that achievement it's too mean) but if you read this along side the thousands of over reviews that have likely talked about what I have not and are still interested in getting this game, you absolutely should! 

Thank you Videocult for making such a wonderful game.

149061001.review:
I've played this game since before 1.5 and Downpour, and still keep coming back to it as my friends discover it for the first time for an experience they'll never forget.

You control the unenviable after they are separated from their family and habitat by a rain storm, washing them through a labyrinth of still-functioning infrastructure that fights against the reclamation of nature.   
You don't know where you are, you don't know how to get back, and the strange yellow creature that greets you after you gain control gives you scarce, fleeting advice before you're eaten by a hissing green monster. 
... then you try again.  

The gameplay loop has you learning a deceptively simple three-button control scheme as you struggle to feed yourself, hibernate, and progress a mysterious counter that seems to gate your progress through the game; You'll quickly begin to appreciate that while survival for the regrettable slugcat is harsh, the world isn't about you- The meticulously detailed and foreign environments you traverse feature functional ecosystems that you are merely a conveniently sized snack for, not an explicit target. 

This is where the game can be polarizing. It's very old-school in it's design and is, as the kids say, "Nintendo Hard". It's design philosophy of tossing you into an alien world and leaving you to learn it's rules extends from the more advanced movement techniques to unclear UI elements. You do get a guide that will attempt to point you in the right direction, but they are driven by procedural behaviors and can be inconsistent at best. 
I do respect that some folks won't enjoy this game, but for anyone that is shying away at my previous description: Just wait a moment-

The difficulty is important. 

I won't tell you that you MUST play this game regardless of your personal tastes, but if you can pay out the patience the game demands, it will absolutely pay you back. 
Rain World is a game with a very carefully crafted narrative and intent to its environmental story-telling, with moments and revelations that still to this day give me chills and make me tear up a bit; And that's not including the Downpour DLC.  

If you still want the story without the difficulty, the game has always had mods and now includes official quality of life features to adjust it as you need.

If you want a classic styled cinematic platformer with a rich cast of creatures that simulate a fascinating ecosystem, absolutely, cannot recommend enough. 
If you want a deeply introspective and surprisingly philosophical story that thrives on your actual struggles as a player, this game will live in your head for decades to come. 

Oh and there's official co-op support. Just be sure to go through the effort of setting up Parsec (and maybe reWASD for sharing keyboard inputs) as my experience with Steam Remote Play is... inconsistent. 

For any of my friends I forced to play this game: I'm not sorry :)

148996479.review:
A good game ruined by terrible controls.

In detail, the movement is quite good and the combat feels nice. Therefore, I am more referring to the player input as Rain World really struggles with that. I am coming from a keyboard which might mean this isn't a problem on gamepads but, whenever you need to interact with some kind of vertical platforming everything falls apart. 
I wanna start with the good things because it's important to understand why this major flaw nullifies every system and makes it impossible to enjoy the game. 

The environment, music and creatures are really well done. You wanna get lost in this world and explore it. I felt the strong urge to sink many hours into this game and all of its components work beautifully together to invoke that feeling. The little encouncters, how enemies and other bugs interact with each other and the soundscape are magnificent to create this dystopian place you survive in. Art design in particular is some of Rain World's strongest bits. Hence why it's so frustrating that it's impossible to stay immersed.

The problem really lies within how either the maps are designed or how controls are handeld. One of these systems kind of create this tragedy.

You see, a perfect example is when the environment slowly starts to shake, the rain is coming and the suspense start rising. You are jumping from platform to platform and the whole progress you made that day is almost finished. All you need to do is make your way back which you've prepared in advance by remembering the route and therefore you're certain that it's easy. But then you encounter a horizontal pipe leading to a smaller horizontal pipe above you inbetween two stones. One of those stones has a vertical pipe. You need to press spacebar to jump and then w to grab the pipe above you. Sadly when you do that your slugcat instantly gravitates towards the vertical pipe next to it and then grabs it. You then need to press space again to let go of it and reset the position a couple of times but by then the rain killed you already because it kept teleporting you again and again for like 10 times. Looking at you pipeyard.

Another instance is when you slept in a dead-end like the garbage wastes and need to do a climbing action on a rather tall wall. Spacebar is also the same input for crawling that last bit of a wall and the walljump which frustrates when you are trying to get over it and you don't have the space to do a backflip or throw-jump so your slugcat is just constantly walljumping until it works after the 5th or 6th try. 

Especially climbing pipes after a walljump is something that just works on a coinflip. Regardless of pressing w your slugcat refuses to grab it and falls into its death. 

Which leads me to the conclusion that the map design is either bad and shouldn't have these types of platforming sections or the controls on keyboard need a giant improvement. Because of this all of your immersion just goes down the drain, your day progress gets resetted and it stops sucking you into its world. 
I played for around 12 hours and tried again and again to love this game. And I actually like everything about it but this flaw makes it impossible to play the campaign when you regularly get stuck in situations mentioned above for minutes at a time until some creature just kills you or you fall into your death without even doing the input. 

The remix improvement were turned on and I have no problem with platforming in general. I suspect I need to say this because it's easy to blame the player but honestly I've tried many times. Celeste 100% wasn't a problem for me. Katana Zero's highest difficulty wasn't either a problem. And the simulation focus on Rain World is even something I enjoyed, the general platforming is good. Pouncing over cliffs and out-maneuvering enemies is fun especially with the combat. It isn't the game feel that I have a problem with which just makes it so frustrating because I like the game.

Hoping for a patch or a mod to appear because I still wanna finish it and give it more tries.

Positives:
- the game looks and sounds good
- actually a good simulator
- the animation system is funny
- poles/beams
- hiding from and avoiding predators is fun
- the lore is pretty nice and has great spiritual resonance
- nice community
- sizeable DLC waiting if you like the base game

Negatives:
- doesn't feel much like a designed game, extremely rough around the edges in general
- the skill curve is a messy rollercoaster
- the controls are not fun to use and take a long time to get used to
- ledges
- maneuvers that make traversal fun instead of painful are extremely obscure (it would be fine if it was fun already at the skill floor, but it's not)
- too much randomness in guidance makes it confusing instead of useful
- too much randomness in food and threats makes you artificially lose time or fail attempts to progress altogether
- while not too punishing in itself, way too much to allow for the necessary experimentation, and it's tiring to get back to the same point again
- possibility to get softlocked if you didn't figure out an optional mechanic by yourself earlier on
- requires a certain player action which makes little to no sense, as it amounts to giving up on trying to find the solution, to progress at some point
- in no way similar to other games which's communities usually recommend it

Don't play this game if you are too used to handholdy games that don't require any thought to learn.
I've played a fair few games, but this is my favourite ever.
This game is unfair, yes, we know that already. That should be made clear to you upon your first ten deaths to the same thing, because you don't get taught anything about how to move on. Such is the life of a slugcat, and you need to accept that if you want to make any progress.
You are alone.
There is nobody to help you.
There is nothing that will help you.
From start to finish, you play as a pitifully weak creature called Slugcat, and there are no upgrades, nothing to show for your progression... Except for your own skill. Like the slugcat, every cycle and every death comes with the knowledge to improve yourself. There are no powerups, no level ups, no stats. Just your sense, your understanding of the world, and your skill. 
In my opinion, there is no game out there more immersive and more intense than Rain World.

Until you try riding a reindeer, and then you're cursing the day you ever bought this stupid ahh game, but lets ignore that......

148875741.review:
Im very split about how I feel about this game.
Ill start with the good stuff:

The visuals and overall atmosphere are really solid.
The few times the soundtrack gets to play always makes me stop whatever I was doing and listen.
Being dropped coldly into this ecosystem and finding your place in it is a completely unique concept that I have never seen being explored by other games. I also generally enjoyed its survival aspects.

However the game is often repetetive and frustrating.
I dont really get where the fun in the gameplay is supposed to be coming from:
The platforming is rather slow, unresponsive and clunky not to mention the claustrophobic leveldesign that at times completely removes that aspect from the game.

"Maybe its about exploration" I thought. But the games systems dont reward or encourage exloration either: If you explore you die. Either becuase of unfamiliar terrain, enemies or because of the rains. Speeking of... do you remember the rain in BotW? How it would hinder you from climbing that mountain? Now imagine that but ten times worse. Why would there be a time limit for exploration? The rains either lead to you retreating back to your previous hibernation spot or to a miserable death somewhere on the way to the next one. I basically always chose the latter which ment I would explore the rain world bit by bit each time getting a little further. This wouldnt be to bad if it wasnt for the karma system, you see each time you die your karma level drops. And like I said you die a lot. But when your karma level is too low you cant get past the gates to the next area anymore which basically makes all your progress pointless and leads to you grinding your karma level back up again.

Ive played up to the Shaded Citadel the games third area and its giving me Tomb of the Giant vibes. To give an example as to why I think its poorly designed; the area is completely dark. The only way to see anything is by grabbing some glowing animal. However because of its weight, carrying it reduces your jump hight, causing some jumps to be unreasonably frustrating or straight up impossible. I saw that the monk class can see in the dark but I dont want to start from the beginning all over again. 
I dont know wether Im gonna push through and finish the game or if im gonna move on to something else. I can definetly imagine me competely changing my mind about this game if I get to see the end and ending up loving it but as of now this is my recomendation:

Is rain world a bad game? No. Is it a masterpiece? Hell no. Is it worth your time and money? Possibly, if youre really curious for it. Just dont set your hopes too high.

148851211.review:
This game, oddly, feels like Titanfall 2 in it's movement & difficulty. Sure, it's easy to move around, but if you want to learn to move like a real SlugCat (like a real Pilot), there is a long & tall skill curve to climb.

   Also like TF2 multiplayer, every other creature in Rain World starts out being absurdly more powerful, capable, & harder to kill than you. Unless you can stack the odds in your favor, or learn to move like a ninja slug, you're going to die a lot before you "git gud."

   Personally, I recommend looking up the lore & some tutorials to help you understand what the hell is going on, & learn the basics of movement. As you master basics, learn the more advanced techniques. Personally, I've enjoyed the challenge of learning the movement, as I did in TF2 (RIP).

   Really fun, once you embrace the randomness, difficulty, & exploration. In this game more than many, "Journey before Destination" applies tremendously.

   If you don't like exploring, overcoming adversity, & developing your in-game movement (IRL Keyboard commando) skills, then this game might not be for you. 

   Or at least, those were the reasons I've thoroughly enjoyed it, especially after watching a nearly 2hr vid explaining the exceedingly cryptic lore of this game.

148820678.review:
This game is absolutely stunning, brutal, and, in my opinion, the best simulation of an ecosystem I have ever seen. The controls (again, for me) feel smooth once you get the hang of them, and jumping around from pole to pole to move faster feels very rewarding. 

[ GOOD THINGS ]

- The predators and prey feel very expertly coded. I cant predict what they are gonna do next, and in most cases, I have to wildly flee myself before I get mauled.

- This game is not easy. I will mention this in the bad section aswell, but not giving the player the power of god, or a double jump, feels smart. If an overseer recommends I go somewhere that i cant reach, i will keep trying to get there, in various ways, if needed, because i know it is possible for me to get there. 

- The soundtrack, character design, and rain system feel flawless aswell. The game gives me a capacity to roam and be awake, but if you stay out too long, then you need to get moving to a shelter and NOW.

[ BAD THINGS ]

- This game is hard. You will not be fed the next area on a silver spoon, and grabbing fruit or grabbing batflies can be challenging. The rain can catch you. The lizards can. Any number of predatory animals or plants can reset you a cycle. But it isnt listlissly impossible hard, as most guides make it seem. Go at your own pace, run away from lizards instead of fighting them, if you want. This worlds only limit is time and skill.

Overall, I love this game, but you dont have to play if you dont want to. Just go at your own pace :]

148696781.review:
Another game with mixed feelings and a complicated love and hate relationship I have with it.
You see, Rain Wolrd nails it in the long run, but most players will be deterred to even want to touch this game again in the first few hours of playing it.

The learning curve is steep, even with Monk and the unforgiving nature of the game that mainly plays in chunks of running from one savepoint to the other make it a frustrating experience way too often. You will die, you will die a lot and some of these deaths are sadly attributed to awkward keybinds and controls as well as just having the worst luck during a cycle (looks at you rain deer section in farming arrays). So be warned and don't take it too hard when you are on your 20th try to get through a section of the game.
Which is quite tragic considering that the game offers a very well thought out world, with tons and tons of tiny details, all wrapped up in enigmatic dialogue and a stunning pixel art landscape. You can feel that there was a lot of passion poured into this strange and tragic world, ready to be explored by those ready to put up with its ups and downs.

Overall would I recommend Rain World?
If you are more on the casual side and don't have much patience to put up with it, no.
If you are however willing to learn its ways, pretty much, as it will reward you for it in the end.

148667242.review:
[h1]Much more than just a cute 2D platformer[/h1]

At first glance, Rain World seemed to me like just another cute little indie platformer. When I downloaded it, I did so along with Ori and Planet of Lana in an effort to stock up on 2D games I could play on a laptop. I was in for a rude awakening when I realized that this was a survival game in a harsh and brutal environment with complex and nuanced enemy design and an overwhelmingly large, scary, yet beautiful world.

The following is a detailed review of everything I thought the game did well and did poorly from the perspective of a completionist with all achievements and over 240 hours of gameplay. Since I absolutely adore this game, let’s get the negative points out of the way first.

[h3]What the game does wrong[/h3]

[b]The control scheme is god awful[/b]
The entire game is controlled with 2 buttons. Every action in the game is basically the jump button or the pick-up button or one of those combined with a directional input or with each other. This can lead to extremely frustrating situations where you’ll be fumbling around trying to pick up or drop or eat certain items but won’t be able to because all 3 of those actions are the same button. This is probably done to simplify the controls since the game is already very harsh in other regards and can be easily remedied with fan-made steam workshop mods.

[b]The randomness of the world can be frustrating at times[/b]
Rain World is a massive complex ecosystem where enemy encounters and behavior can depend on a multitude of factors. Spawns are fixed but how the game’s creatures decide what to do and where to go is very dynamic in nature. Although this is one of the most beautiful aspects of the game, it can also be the most frustrating. It’s fairly common to encounter situations where the events of a cycle will play out in the most unfortunate possible way. Predators can block exits and just sit there or block an access pipe, aerial threats will attack at the worst time imaginable, or a friendly creature that is absolutely necessary to progress will just refuse to cooperate, etc. This is, in my opinion, a small price to pay in exchange for the sheer excitement of the game’s dynamism but can still be infuriating sometimes.

[h3]What the game does right[/h3]

[b]Gorgeous visuals with a unique art style[/b]
This will ultimately come down to whether or not you’re a fan of pixel art, but if you are, then this game is nothing short of beautiful. Every area is visually appealing in its’ own way, with its’ own color pallete and theme. From industrial gutters, to abandoned underground train tracks, to a night-time metropolis, to a bridged complex overlooking a rainbow filled skyline. All dark and unsettling yet uniquely gorgeous.

[b]A massive and intricate world[/b]
Rain World’s map is overwhelmingly large. It is comprised of over a dozen regions, each with their own aesthetic and their own fauna and flora. Each region has tons of things to explore, enemies to encounter, and different paths to take. As you pour more and more hours into the game, you’ll get a feel for how all the areas connect to each other and how best to path your way through the world on the way to different goals or objectives. There are always multiple ways from A to B at any given moment and what path you take, or what regions you choose to trek through or avoid is entirely up to you.

[b]A dark and gritty atmosphere[/b]
The game has a unique way of inspiring a sense of dread which is represented in all manner of forms. You’re travelling through a long abandoned/forgotten industrial area, in a race against the rainfall with the constant threat of predators around every corner. The world you’re in is harsh and unforgiving and simply surviving while finding enough food to hibernate at the next shelter is a real challenge. It’s a unique thrill with the stress of avoiding hazards and evading predators juxtaposed with the sheer euphoria of finding food or a shelter in an unexplored area. Combine this weird dichotomy of emotions with a dark and dreadful world and then throw in a beautifully melancholic soundtrack and you get a unique atmosphere unlike any game I’ve played.

[b]A profoundly beautiful story under the surface[/b]
I won’t get into any story spoilers here but the game’s story is very deep and meaningful. The story isn’t presented to you up-front, but is always lying in the background waiting to be pieced together by dilligent players. The story also takes place over a timeline with each of the main and DLC characters contributing a small part to the greater picture.

[b]A living breathing ecosystem[/b]
The creatures in Rain World are vastly different from one another in their appearance and behavior. This can range from friendly to fearful to neutral to hyper-aggressive. Each creature has an optimal way to be dealt with, along with it’s place in the food chain and will behave according to a complex set of built-in relationships between them. A predator that wants to eat you may be scared off or killed by an even larger threat. A fight between two predators can provide an opportunity to slip past, which can sometimes even save you after being caught in the jaws of a predator. Some creatures have a reputation system with the player and will react to the player differently according to what their current standing with the player is. Certain predators can be fed to tame them, at which point they will follow you around and defend you (as long as you continue to feed them). Creatures will hunt, kill, and flee from each other and all these interactions are unfolding in the world constantly, even without the player’s presence. This furthers the sensation that this dauntingly massive and unforgiving world exists with or without you and you are only a small part of it.

[b]The best DLC I have ever seen offered for a game[/b]
Downpour more than doubles the amount of content the game offers for a fraction of the price. Downpour adds a whopping 5 playable characters that each have their own campaigns, unique mechanics, and new stories that take place at different points in the timeline which serve to fill in the gaps and paint a more complete picture of the events that take place. Each campaign also includes character exclusive regions and slightly altered areas based on the campaign’s placement in the timeline. One of the campaigns even features[spoiler]a complete ice age reskin of the entire world map + the collapse of one zone onto another.[/spoiler] Each of these characters and their campaigns could easily be their own DLC and I would happily buy them, but Downpour adds FIVE of them which is a gargantuan amount of extra content to an already content-rich game.

[u]TL;DR[/u]
I started Rain World expecting to play a cute little platformer and what I got instead was a brutally harsh yet thoroughly enjoyable survival game. It was a journey through a beautifully crafted world with a complex ecosystem and a profoundly deep story under the game’s surface. It offers an overwhelming amount of content to enjoy and only gets more gratifying the more hours you put into it.

148556446.review:
Game literally changed my life. Rain World made me understand people who fixate on the same game for a very long time even after they've already done everything in it. There is no experience like Rain World and I'm almost a little sad to think there will never be anything new like it in my life again. Go in as blind as you possibly can and do not look up guides unless you are well and truly stuck, and even then, I suggest checking the wiki for the region you're in and simply guiding yourself to one you HAVEN'T been in instead of looking for the actual goal of the game- Trust me, as aimless as it can feel at first, the joy of discovery in Rain World is THE appeal. It will either be extremely right for you or you will not be into it at all. Learning the controls is the biggest hurdle, but I found it very fun after getting over the frustration.
If you're patient, and (not to sound pretentious, but it's how I feel) you drop your preconceptions about how and what games "should" be, you will find this game insanely rewarding. I never in a million years would have considered myself the type of person to enjoy this game before I played it, but I am sincere when I say I am a different person having played it. Please give it a try.

148536763.review:
Pros:
- Incredibly unique gaming experience
- Phenomenal background storytelling
- Progression based solely on one's knowledge and skill
- Responsive and in-depth movement system
- Fantastic ecosystem; game does a great job at making you feel helpless
Cons:
- Screen cutoffs in big, open areas that can often get you killed
- Really useful and life-saving movement tech left completely hidden from the player (without DLC)
- Can easily make new players feel stuck/lost (God forbid you go to Farm Arrays and not Drainage/Industrial in your first playthrough)
- Jungle Leeches (I will find the sick individual/s who designed these things)

This game will unapologetically beat the living hell out of every new player and piss on their unconscious bodies as they're down. But if you're persistent (and quite honestly insane enough) to keep trying and learn, you'll experience one of the most breathtaking and unique 2D exploration gaming experiences to date. Is the game perfect? Hell no. Far from it. Is it worth sinking many hours into and even more with the DLC? Absolutely.

9/10 would swim in the sentient corn-infested soup again

148463988.review:
When I opened this game, I thought this was going to be a relaxing experience... [i]I'm so sorry, little one, but I was sorely mistaken.[/i]


[h1]Introduction[/h1]
I'll start off with what I would classify this game as, because it's a pretty unique experience. In short, it's an environmental survival and resource-management platformer sprinkled with a bit of rogue-lite in there. To be honestly with you, the closest game that I've played that I could compare it to is Noita for it's brutality and platforming, but that's about where the similarities end.

Would I recommend this game? Yes, but it has an acquired taste. There will be b*llshit deaths that you can't control. There will be no-win situations. The phrase "What the F*CK IS THAT??!?" will be said countless times during your time in the brutal setting of Rain World. However, what this game excels at is creating a beautiful ecosystem to observe and realize that you are only a very small part of. Let's get into that more, shall we?

[h2]The Strengths[/h2]
The environment of this game is extremely well done, down to the smallest detail, and much of this is due to how enemies work. Not only are the level layout and aesthetics gorgeous and gritty, but the enemies feel at home there. Different factions of creatures are in specific places of the map, but can venture out, fighting other factions or even amongst themselves. Furthermore, the "day" cycle of the game (going to keep this spoiler free) determines what enemies are out, and let me tell you, when the day is ending, even your WORST enemies simply want to survive like you do. All of these tiny interactions of the AI are what make experiencing this game truly special, because no run through the same area will be same. Getting ambushed by a massive enemy swooping out of nowhere at the beginning of an area? Well, even though your expecting it on the next run it never comes. The enemies are not simply roadblocks for the player, they are a part of the world, just like the player.

Also, this game can be horribly terrifying, especially when you stumble across new enemies (which happens often). I cannot tell you how many times I have entered a new room, seen what sort of abomination lies with in only to turn tail and run immediately. If this game has one thing to saw, it is that you are not the main character, you are only a small yet integral part of the world you find yourself in...

Overall, this game is great, but only if you're OK with a few b*llshit moments here and there. Otherwise, learning the game and how it works is a joy, and I'm still finding interactions that I've never seen previously. Would recommend, and good luck, fellow slugcat!

148395438.review:
Beginner Tips: 
- when you wake up in outskirts (starting region), DO NOT GO INTO FARM ARRAYS OR DRAINAGE SYSTEM UNTIL YOU UNDERSTAND MORE ABOUT THE GAME. everywhere else is great tho, have fun

- find someone who you want to play this game with, preferably someone who can show you the ropes, but also just in general. both parties do not need to own the game, just takes one person owning and inviting another person

- try not to look online for resources and just discover the world yourself, but don't feel like it's taboo to figure out how to play your game. the community has a weird overemphasis on this and I think it honestly drives more people away than it keeps. imo this game doesn't to a great job at communicating different directions you can go, and I encourage people to figure out how to develop better tools that can help guide new players around without spoiling everything and leaving more discovery up to the player.

- this game has very different feeling between controller and keyboard, with both being able to do different tricks and such. I prefer keyboard, but you should try both out to see which fits you better

- get downpour, it is seriously great and adds a TON to the world and game.

- the camera takes some getting used to, but you will get used to it don't worry. alternatively, there are camera scrolling mods available on the workshop if you just can't handle it

- there is not any one path to get anywhere, in face there's usually two or three, sometimes four. whether it's within a region, or across multiple regions.

Intermediate Tips:
- when the game starts to feel easier, get a slugpup! it's a nifty way to challenge yourself, especially if you can't push yourself to do harder challenges yet. 

- expedition mode can get extremely fun once you've unlocked a bunch of perks, but it can be tough getting there unless you cheese or grind a few expeditions.

148300028.review:
I understand this game isn't for everyone. However, this game is extremely fun if you just spend some time on it. I've seen negative reviews on this game saying that the enemies aren't staying on path and they are always somewhere different or maybe the controls are bad and who could possibly forget THIS GAME TELLS YOU NOTHING. All of this is true but, I think if you checked what you were getting into and you knew the goal of the game then it wouldn't be so bad. If you don't know this game is a game that simulates a living ecosystem in a dying world. You are not important because you are only a part of this ecosystem. This is why the creatures of Rain World can move even off screen and do (almost) whatever they want. This game also gives them the ability to control their own movements with procedural animation. Basically it makes them control their limbs and make the limbs move however they want so, that it pushes itself from point A to point B. This makes it even harder to predict your enemy. I'm no expert on this topic so if you want to actually know how this works watch a video about it. Your character is procedurally animated too so expect lots of cool movements based on how you move your arrow keys. The controls are difficult to get the hang of. This is because the creature you play as is learning how to live without family guidance. you will most likely get used to it and if you look back actually good at it. Once I got eaten by a blue lizard the actual easiest predator in the game. Now I killed a red lizard one of the most difficult lizard in the game. 






Finally lets talk about difficulty...



 Imagine the hardest game you have ever played
times it by 10 and then add a hint of impossible to escape moments.
Yes there is parts of the game that are not fair and unexpected, But is life fair?






In short this game is like "Hey did you think that you are not a top predator? Here lets show you what being at the bottom of the food chain really looks like and lets see if you can climb to the top just like you distant ancestors."

148258125.review:
Rain World is a game I would never recommend to anyone. To try and describe the feelings I have about this game is an essay within itself. Rain World is one of the most impactful, beautiful, frustrating, and down-right cruel games I have ever played in my life. 

This game has fundamentally changed the way I view the world, and not in a generic “Ahaha! I learned about Buddhism!” kind of way. It defies all nature, there is no world where Rain World is not frustrating, there will always be pain attached to this game. 

However despite that you always come back to Rain World, because it is unlike any other game. No Game displays such skill in enemy AI, movement, combat, art and more. It gives me this feeling of Super Smash Bros Melee, a game that beyond all reason should not be successful. A game that almost feels broken, unfinished, or fundamentally flawed, yet a game that surpasses and will continue to surpass all others like it. 

For most, flaws are not what they look for, they want perfection, but for people like you and I, Rain World’s flaws are what makes Rain World… Rain World. 

I love this game.

"Rain world is a melancholic game with a heavy, murky and deep lore about existentialism."

This is one of the best games I have ever played.
With a story and lore so intrinsically built into the world that the experience integrates the player into the world's ecosystem through sheer immersion.

Oh, and I guess it's pretty challenging as well.

I played the game for the longest while the same way I imagined a Slugcat would try and survive. I moved when food got low and avoided confrontation to the best of my ability since there was nearly no benefit to willingly engage something bigger than me in combat.

Yet despite all the difficulty at the beginning I could hunt titans by the end of my journey.
Keep in mind that your skill is the only thing that improves from the beginning of a capaign until its end.. in most campaigns at least.

148103746.review: Una obra de arte. Jugabilidad de 10. Necesitas horas para saber manejarse en el mundo, pero de eso se trata. Se siente un ecosistema vivo, con sus interacciones entre las criaturas mas allá de tu presencia. A parte de que hay profundidad a ese nivel, las criaturas reaccionan a ti y hay acciones que cambian su comportamiento de un ciclo a otro. 148099771.review:
My friend talked about this game a lot, so I decided to try it out, not knowing if I would like it since I don't play platformer games (except for Little Big Planet a long time ago). I had heard about the technical features it had, and since I am a developer myself, I wanted to see. When I loaded into the game, the art already looked beautiful. The movement was a little hard to get the hang of on the keyboard, but I quickly switched to a controller, and it was a lot better.

By far, I have to say that this is one of my top three games I've ever played or seen, and I've played over 300 different games across all platforms. The gameplay and movement were extremely fun to learn, and the lore was even better. Since it has remote play support, I can get many of my friends, who never bought the game, to adventure with me.

There were many times when we were struggling to beat some parts (cough cough the wall on Artificer cough cough), but eventually, we did get through it. Throughout the entire game, I always had fun in some way. Even just practicing PvP in competitive or learning how to perform a difficult movement skill, I was always having fun.

If you are going to get the game, here are a few things to keep in mind:

Make sure that you buy the DLC! It quadruples the game's content and is even better than the base game.
It is quite challenging to play, so be prepared.
DO NOT SPOIL THE GAME FOR YOURSELF. Half of the fun of the game is understanding what is happening in the world.

Overall, I would say that this game is a masterpiece to play. If you are considering buying the game, just try it out! And if you don't like it, refund it (trust me, you won't have to).
