148084499.review:
One of those games that you'll never really forget.

Very unique, challenging, punishing, rewarding, so much fun. Buy the DLC if you enjoyed playing the base game, it has more content than the base game and is really enjoyable and well made. Definitely worth the price unlike many AAA games.

The AI is top tier and really lively, the pixel art and environments are amazing. This game has a lot to say if you're into lore and philosophy, but if you're not you can just play it for fun and enjoy the ride. 

This game does not hold your hand at all and lets you make all the decisions. 

Some advice for beginners: This game is really hard at times, so if you're really struggling don't feel ashamed to play the "easy" mode and choose monk. In this game the easy mode is still pretty hard if you're new to the game and is really more comparable to the "normal" mode in any other game. I played monk for my first ever run and still found it difficult. If you find yourself getting lost and not knowing what to do, don't be afraid to look at the wiki or a guide. 

One of best games i've ever played, 100% recommend

148030890.review:
This is one of the best games I've ever played.
Probably my favorite game of all time.
It has amazing environments, sound design, and beautiful art and music. 
The main campaigns have tear-jerking stories, and I love how the player is meant to infer and piece together the lore from the environment and what little information you are given. I also adore how the game doesn't hold your hand and emphasizes exploration and figuring things out yourself, i rarely had to pull up a wiki to figure stuff out, if at all.
Some things I personally would like to see improvement on:
Certain areas of the map being improved to remove invisible walls, I think it breaks the immersion. Maybe replacing them with some physical barrier that fits in with the environment.
Small fixes to creature spawns and AI softlocking you (notable example is the caramel lizard in farm arrays by the gate to outskirts, which could also be fixed by just making the shelter a little bit bigger.)
I also really appreciate the dev team's efforts to fix modding on Linux.
i really don't have much to complain about, most of the game is really well made and the current bugs and goofs are so minor.
I do realize the gameplay isn't for everyone, but if you love exploration and discovering things for yourself you will love this game, it also provides a great challenge.

I want to play the Rain World that I hear people talk about.

For as many unique things this game does, I can't recommend it to the average person. There are so many points of frustration that need some quality of life attention, especially rerolling the mob spawns and grinding food for gates. I also think the second area (Drainage System) leaves an especially bad impression compared to the amount of freedom in the first area. Hitting credits ended up being more force than fun. If you are a fan of punishing platformers like Super Meat Boy or even Jump King and want a less breakneck pace, give this one a try. If you come in expecting an open-world exploration game where you survive by hunting your own food... you are like me, misled by some VERY loose definitions of those words. Good luck!

148001684.review: This game is an absolute masterpiece. Everything about it is perfect. The game is hard to describe, but I like to call it an Immersive Survival Simulator. This is because you have everything you need to survive a harsh, cruel and hopeful world. Every impact or action you make, will drastically or minimally affect the world around you and in the future, but it isn't a choice driven game. The story, as hard as it is to find for yourself, is a tragic tale. The world building and environments are gorgeous and look like they jumped straight out of a painting. The physical and sound design is immaculate, being both adorable and horrifying as well as alien but still familiar. This game offers endless replayability and hours of enjoyment and suffering. This game is hard, if you are up for the challenge of a lifetime, one that will take hours, days or even weeks of your life away, you will experience a game like no other. Please, I beg you to try this game out. 10/10

You yourself have to discover the story, and once you put together the pieces it lets you enjoy it to its fullest.

147921148.review:
For me this game first and foremost is a feeling of silent dread of the world that is abandoned, which inspires the feeling of fleetingness of life. Through all the characters and epochs we witness the world decaying, as nothing actually mattered and is ready to meet the Void. At the same time we are reminded that the cycle is unending and will start anew.

This game is my favorite among indie titles and not without a reason. Many talk about its unprecedented natural habitat simulation and dynamic animations, fluidness of movement, steep learning curve, art style, story and lore. For me its all of these things combined into something almost flawless as an experience. It might be not the best gaming you will ever get, even though its really solid and fun soon as you dive head first and submerge yourself properly. But it is The Experience.

It only got better with Downpour. I cannot sing enough praises to the developers that worked of DLC that worked so much time on it by their lonesome. Videocult is also to be commended as they worked towards bringing DLC developers on board. Downpour introduced so much into story and contextualized many elements from the original game, at the same time largely expanding The Experience. 

In conclusion, I would like to say that the game might not be everyone's cup of tea, This review is purely subjective and comes from heart. But if you find other reviews to your liking and looking for something hard, stylish, alive and thoughtful - you just might be in luck.

147870615.review:
This game is legitimately one of my favorite games in the world. While you start the game not knowing much else other than the fact that you are a little creature and must find a way to survive, once you get further into the game you realize just how rich the world is! Everything feels alive in this game and no two runs are the same. Hell, even each cycle is completely different, even if you're in the same area! 

The replayability for this game is insane! Even more so if you have the DLC which I 100% do recommend if you enjoy the base game. While the game is already one that you can replay over and over, if you do find things getting a bit stale then look at the workshop! The modding community for this game is astounding and it seems that every day there is new mods to add and try out! From cosmetics to game aids to new fan made areas, enemies, or even completely new slug cats to play as with their own mechanics! You can also play with friends through remote play so only one of you need to own the game. 

I will warn you that the game can get incredibly frustrating at times- especially when you're newer to the game as there is a complete lack of hand holding. You will die *a lot*, but its just part of the game. If that doesn't stop you from turning away completely I really do suggest you try it out! 

This game is so incredibly beautiful. The music, art, story- everything is amazing! As far as I've seen there really is no game like this one. If you want a game that will challenge you or you love a game that has amazing lore or of course if you like just being a little creature then this is the game for you!!

147845665.review:
[h1] Rain World is a really difficult and immersive world that lets you experience how it feels to fear death every other second. [/h1]

Rain World is a beautiful looking game, with gorgeous enviroments inside a world that (for the most part) uses it's eviroments to paint you the picture of the world around you.
Exploring the world that is presented to you in this game can be a ball crushing, spirit breaking and all in all complicated journey, with everything in the world have the slightest chance to murder you in cold blood in 1 or 2 seconds. Having to manouver through the pain is something that you NEED to learn in this game, and even after fully completing this game, I don't fully grasp it tbh (damn.)
trekking through the terrain, fully grasping each Slugcats story to its conclusion and learning the mechanisms of the existence of every being is a journey I'm glad I followed through to the end and would NOT do it again. I love this game, but I suck at it I wouldn't retry it, loved it though.

[h2] Downpour [/h2]

The mod turned DLC of Rain World was quite enjoyable to me. The additional Slugcats used to expand the story that the game tells is something I found quite nice and the explanation of the reasons for the actions of certain caracters, the future of the world and it's conclusion was a tale I really enjoyed reading.
Although the enjoyment of the DLC is heavily conflicted due to how different it feels to the main game with it including:
[olist]
    [*]Slugcats having more in-depth [i][And impossible to explain in an evolution standpoint][/i] mechanics
    [*]The story being more explicitly told to the player
    [*]The writing which some persons find cringy [i][Which personally I only agree on the use of ~ to convey emotions])[/i]
[/olist]
I honestly don't think these are necessarily bad points. The expansion serves as more of a add-on to the game, it gives the player new ways to explore the land of Rain World, gives existing characters more depth and reason and creates their own characters (in the form of the Slugcats) with their own personalities, purpose and reasons, and gives a cool [i](though really strange)[/i] "conclusion" to the story.
Spoilers to Saints Campaign:
[spoiler] Like honestly I don't know why they though to give Saint ascension powers but like pop off ig[/spoiler]


[h2] 100% [/h2]
Rain World is hard as balls to 100%. Although most achievements require just finishing campaigns, completing certain objectives or finding [spoiler]Echoes[/spoiler], the game's already high difficulty makes completing the game quite the lengthy task.
Aside from the main story objectives, Downpour adds two new gamemodes with their own objetives:
[list]
    [*]Challenges: A series of scenarios of where you have to complete certain objectives in order to win.
    [*]Expedition Mode: Play the game in any campaign with a set of objectives that you need to complete in order to win.
[/list]
Challenges were fun to try and try again until I finally won after a long series of attempts.
Expedition made me want to die and I would NOT try it again ill be completely honest. I like the game, but if I have to go through specific objectives with the danger of permadeath ever again I'll scream.

[h2] Recommendation [/h2]
I only recommend this game if you have extreme patience and are willing to endure a challenge that may seem just really hard at times and really unfair at others.
The story the base game and DLC give is really well thought out and I got quite compelled by the narrative that it presented, being one of the games where I actually decided to look into the lore on my own just to learn more about it.
It's not a game for everyone, but if you really like challenging platformers or are willing to endure it, I fully recommend it

[h3] TL;DR [/h3]
[list]
    [*]Beautiful pixel and non-pixel art
    [*]Really good and compelling story
    [*]Hard as balls
[/list]

147828529.review:
It's a very good game and there is certainly some directions and instructions given to you at parts. Whether or not you'll survive long enough or figure things out to get to those early points is another story.

While there's many things Rain World does right, the question posed is "would you recommend it?" and I look back at my 13.5 hours spent and say that the game is fun, there's variety and many pathways through areas, the freedom is great and being able to go wherever you'd like (mostly) is a big plus. That's where the compliments end though, I can't in good conscience recommend this to other people who want to jump in and start having fun, you need to at least have a goal in mind to work towards before you start to really appreciate some titles and... I don't think that surviving while dying many times over is enough of that to motivate some to keep playing.

My review is not for fans of Rain World. In fact I suppose it may well be looked upon as my not giving the game enough of a chance, the discussions might even scoff at my measly 13.5 hours and a lot of them would dismiss my review as bad for not having the time put in. Some would argue my review should be wrote after my first playthrough but I tell you this now, you can't get an unbiased review from somebody clearly in love with the game, so before Rain World takes me deeper into its clutches I'll keep my thoughts as they are, I am not converted yet and I think it fills its niche very well.

If I had to leave somebody reading this with parting thoughts on whether or not to buy the game. Consider if you enjoy games where some paths will be dead ends, backtracking is where you'll spend a chunk of your time, consulting a guide may be necessary for some to enjoy the game. Now read that last point again, so I ask you.. can I really recommend a game where a guide may in some instances be necessary for players to start enjoying it?

The answer to the above is yes I could. However I am not going to, this is because I respect your time and I believe your time is better spent on other games. Oh but I will add that if you find this game cheap enough it is probably worth sinking that initial half hour or an hour in to get your feet wet, the general vibe you start out with persists throughout the rest of the game so it is in my novice opinion a good indicator.

Edit: I have finished The Survivor since publishing this review and while I have mixed feelings on the ending it was overall good. The steps to achieve it are downright brutal however, with no "easy" path.. I mean I get it, fine the game can be a bit harder towards the last milestones.

What my complaint here is that the final area overstays its welcome, you go into a very hazey and vague area with no clear shapes, head towards something and then after a couple steps you finish.. in theory. It's not often I actually pause at the very final stretch to check if I'm doing something wrong but here in Rain World I had to pause and check multiple times, there's just nothing happening for a good few minutes with barely any change and that's normal. Then at the very very last part of it all you go do something else to trigger the ending, the problem here is THERE'S NO CLEAR INDICATOR TO DO SO, JUST A VERY VAGUE ONE.

To be clear I don't have it in for Rain World, there's a reason I stayed up until the ending and I'm not done with it. It is so much more frustrating to me that the final bit could be so confusing. Still not recommended.

147735045.review:
This game has genuinely consumed me ever since I decided to look into it.
I saw it years ago and didn't think much, but then I actually tried the game for myself and delved into the lore and MAN it is all I've been able to think about.
This has genuinely become one of my favourite games ever.

The gameplay is incredibly fun- unforgiving at times, yes, but I personally enjoy the challenge and unfairness. I especially liked messing around in expeditions once I figured them out! That and the movement tech!! It's so much fun to learn! :]
The music is GODLY. Very fun to have on in the background. If I could have some sort of physical copy of it I would.
The characters are so captivating and the story is SO GOD DAMN HEARTWRENCHING but OHH it is worth it. I love seeing everyone's theories-- I love how creative everything is.

This review doesn't have the greatest formatting but I thought to finally share my love for this game. I've bought it twice for myself and five times for friends- and I doubt I'll stop anytime soon!

Once you get past the learning curve you really start to see your improvement, and that itself is an exhilarating feeling. That you're getting /better/!
I genuinely strongly recommend this game. Most fun I've had in ages and I've never gotten bored :]

147718291.review:
This is one of my favorite games on Steam.

The ecosystem is so complex and beautiful.

I love this game because it's not like most games where you start out strong and powerful or you grow to be powerful, you stay the same. A slugcat, a snack for predators. You don't get stronger. You don't develop new abilities. You just... stay you. Your performance in the game can improve as you play more, learning to survive better, but you stay you. You survive as you are.

I could play this game all day. It's so beautiful and amazing, and it gives a whole new feeling to it. It's beautiful in its own way... it doesn't matter if the scenery or the creatures are beautiful. The game is.

In this game, you start out as a weak slugcat, and stay one. You will die, but you will adapt and survive. You will explore and wander, finding weapons to defend yourself. You go through cycles (like a day), fatal rain coming at the end of each. You must hibernate in your den to escape it. When you hibernate, the new cycle will begin and the rain's timer will reset. The more you hibernate, the more your karma is raised. If you die, you lose some of that karma.

Each creature is so balanced, and it fits in perfectly. They all have their own reasons to be here, even if not all of them are organic, they're still amazing. It feels just like a real thriving ecosystem. Every area and place is all so detailed. I really love the Scavengers. They're so complex and well-developed.

The only thing relatively bad I have to say about this is how pained the keyboard controls are. But you get used to them after a little.

Believe me. You want this game.

[h1] Score: 8/10 [/h1]
I beat the Survivor Campaing, it took me around 27 hours, pretty fun experience overall and definitely worth experiencing. It is, along Zelda Botw, one of the best games about exploration out there.
[h2] Pros [/h2]
[b]Pretty fair unfair game for the most part[/b], the game doesnt expect you to have a high karma level after some difficulty mid game sections, which is nice, it also raise your karma level in a part where you need to be at maximum karma. It's a game where you will eventually beat it if you keep trying.
[b]Exploring is fun[/b], it's just plain fun, that's the main reason to play the game, the game never get repetitive because each region introduce enough things to keep the game fun.
[b]Gorgeous visuals.[/b] Everything from the locations to the enemies to the slugcats is so charming and memorable.
[b]Pretty memorable soundtrack.[/b] Thou, it's kinda hard to search for specific themes.
[h2] Cons [/h2]
[b]Extremely unreliable Overseer[/b], it was gone for most part of my mid/late game playthrough, I did Unfortunate Development twice because I missed the path to [Redacted]
[b]It doesn't bother to introduce more advanced techniques that make the game more fun.[/b] Just read the wiki of the game.
[b]Pretty simple story.[/b] It'll be hours and hours of basically no story at all, you can get extra lore using pearls, but that requieres a lot of effort and backtracking.
[b]I personally didn't like the last section of the game.[/b] It was hard to see where I could move and I was swimming in the void for 25 minutes. It was not hard or something, just disappointing.
[b]You can't bang Moon.[/b] Originally the score was 8.5/10, but I had to lower it after writting this part of the review.

when i played this game for the first time it was like i when i played Mario for the first time when i was younger

147488764.review:
Before you play!

Understand that this game is hard, and that it is MEANT to be hard. You will die. A lot. There is no avoiding it (unless you use cheats for godmode, in which case what's the point?)

This game's skill ceiling is off of the charts. Different levels of play look drastically different. The movement system is one of the most dynamic in any game ever, and it's ecosystem is well done. You aren't anyone special in this game. You aren't some chosen figure destined for greatness. You are most often just a member of the ecosystem, or OCCASIONALLY a messenger.

If you are a rage gamer, don't play the game. You will dislike it. This game requires MULTIPLE tries to understand how good it is, and if you aren't willing to put in that time or effort, don't play it, it's not for you. The only way you get "stronger" is EXCLUSIVELY by getting better at the game. Literal experience is your XP bar.

Not a metroidvania btw. It has a lot of elements of one, like the different region names and... well that's about it. This is not a metroidvania, as much as Mr Scug looks like Mr Hollow Knight.

Regardless, this is one of my favorite games of all time, up there with the titles of Terraria, Celeste, and Hollow Knight, You just have to get by the difficulty barrier first. It's a high bar.

147242748.review:
I loved the game, it feels like an actual ecosystem that you traverse through as a small animal. You're not strong, but you have tools on hand to aid you.

Now I've finished this game twice, both on monk (essentially "easy mode") and survivor (the second most difficult excluding the DLC). Did I die a lot? Yes. Did it frustrate me at times? yes. You will die, over and over and over again. The game isn't fair, just like how life isn't fair. Things happen out of your control.

To adress those who say the game is too difficult and confusing. Start off as Monk. It is practically the tutorial while also being a story. It gives you tips in between every death and successful cycle. Pay attention to your surroundings, the overseers (the small worm looking creatures that pop out of walls to obeserve you) to guide you to points of interest. Look at their body language and follow them. They are your helping hand. 

I really do recommend you play this game with a controller though, it gives you a bit more control.

If it weren't for the karma system and one minor design choice that exclusively punishes new players, I would recommend this game to everyone. There's nothing worse than finally making it to the next shelter then realizing you have to do it 4 more times in a row with a depleted food supply.

If that wouldn't bother you (or you're fine with disabling it the system in settings/using an exploit like I did), go for it. The game is enraging at times and unfair by design, but even as someone who absolutely sucks at games and gives up easily, it's one of the best experiences I've had. The way the AI works means you'll always have different obstacles to avoid, the environments are massive, the story/lore is very interesting, and the music amplifies it all immensely.

I just... cannot handle the frustration this game forces down upon me. white lizards deciding to fall asleep in a tight corridor and not letting me pass to the area I am trying to go to. a horde of adult centipedes swarming me while I am in complete darkness with overseer giving barely enough light. I do not know what I am supposed to be doing or where I am supposed to be going. I shouldn't have to look up guides online to figure out where to go or what to do. Even after looking up a guide for how to fight these lizards, I still struggle. Either there are no visible weapons nearby, or I am in a tight corridor that does not allow movement. Not to mention, I don't even know how to throw in any direction other than left or right. Is that just me or is that an actual in game mechanic that forbids being able to throw in all directions? Again, I shouldn't be forced to look up a guide for every single thing in this game. I'm sure it's a good game if you can become good at it. (But why play a game that isn't fun for you until later on anyway?)

EDIT: Just wanted to say thank you to the random people and people in my friends list that gave me some tips for the game after they saw this review. That was very cool of you guys and probably the first time I've seen positive feedback from any community.

147062716.review:
This might be a risky recommendation, I will admit, but after just finishing it, I would definitely suggest playing Rainworld, if you have the patience (you'll need a lot of it).

You will frequently hate the game as it mercilessly keeps kicking you down and gives you little sense of direction, but for a very good payoff that puts it all in perspective... or maybe the payoff is as amazing as it is because of the backdrop set by the rest of the game.

Either way, the game definitely gets those spiritual/philosophical juices going, despite explicitly telling you very little. It reduced me to tears at least twice, perhaps even a blubbering mess.

~~~

Bootnote advice:
If you encounter any coloured pearls and pick them up, make sure to put them somewhere safe for the time being (i.e. a shelter), otherwise they'll be gone forever and you'll regret it later.

Also, like others have said, don't be afraid to put the game down and try again later from time to time; it's frustrating and hard, but when you're ready to come back, what seemed like an insurmountable obstacle at the time will now be a piece of cake.

---

Disclaimer: I got this game on discount (not free) through Humble Bundle, but fully intend to buy the DLC through Steam at whatever it's price ends up being at the time.

This game is amazing, if you're someone who likes to explore and piece things together on your own, like enemy behaviour, the world around and its story, or even such things like movement. Rain World is not one bit easy and pretty much everything about this game's design is hostile, but that's what makes it such a persuasive nut to try to crack. If you don't give up, this game will reward you and surprise you about a million times over, and there is no way it's story won't absorb all your thoughts.
This game is mostly platforming adventure, but it's also survival physics sim and it all blends in a very unique way. Although if I were to assign this game to any genre, it would be Art.

P.S.: DLC is amazing as well.

146906153.review:
1. Captivating Art and Atmosphere: Rain World's hand-drawn pixel art creates a visually stunning and atmospheric world. The contrast between its beautiful environments and the harsh, unforgiving ecosystem adds depth to the player's experience.

2. Mysterious and Immersive Narrative: The game's minimalistic storytelling approach encourages players to uncover the narrative through exploration and observation. The world of Rain World is filled with secrets and lore, waiting to be discovered.

3. Unique Ecosystem: Rain World presents an ecosystem teeming with bizarre and interconnected creatures, each with its own behavior and role in the food chain. This ecosystem evolves and adapts as players progress, creating a dynamic and unpredictable world.

4. Challenging Survival Gameplay: Survival is at the core of Rain World's gameplay. Players must navigate treacherous environments, find shelter from the constant rain, hunt for food, and evade or confront hostile creatures. The difficulty adds tension and satisfaction to each successful survival.

5. Gorgeous Sound Design: The game's audio design, including its ambient sounds and haunting musical score, complements the visual beauty and adds to the overall immersion.

6. Nonlinear Exploration: Rain World encourages exploration and experimentation, offering multiple paths and routes to progress. Players are given the freedom to choose their own way through the world, making each playthrough unique.

7. Responsive Controls: The game's controls are precise and responsive, which is crucial for navigating the challenging landscapes and facing off against formidable foes.

8. Deep Lore and Mystery: Rain World's enigmatic world is ripe with lore and unanswered questions, inviting players to theorize and speculate about the story's hidden depths.

9. Unique Multiplayer Experience: The game's multiplayer mode allows players to explore and survive in the world together or compete in a race to reach specific objectives. This cooperative and competitive element adds variety to the gameplay.

In conclusion, Rain World is a mesmerizing and immersive indie title that shines with its captivating art, atmospheric world, and challenging survival gameplay. It offers a unique and unforgettable journey through a harsh and beautiful landscape, where players must adapt and overcome to survive. The game's minimalistic storytelling and open-ended exploration make it a perfect choice for those who appreciate depth and mystery in their gaming experiences. Rain World is not just a game; it's an artistic and atmospheric adventure that leaves a lasting impression on players who dare to explore its captivating world.

146837910.review: Seen people play this has also joining sessions with them now and then. The more i explore this game either way, there is something about this slug cat story and journey in game play and story progression that is so profound and thought provoking that it can't be ignored in this form of art. There is something special here and it's not anyone that can get it. Even me reviewing this has doubts if i really comprehend the intended philosophical meaning of it. keeps me thinking and in a good way despite how heavy or light own conclusions can be. If ur interested in this game cause u saw a trailer or anything related to it and if ur a art lover give it a try.  Recommend it. It is what it is and it's actually good in it own way. Just go with it. follow the journey and make your own decisions "in the dark". Explore. Figure the lore by observing, it's not obvious. In the end it's up to you your own fate. Your own journey conclusion in a world driven by pure instinct and survival.

146746558.review:
It hurts so much to want to like this game, but certain aspects make it completely unplayable for me.  The total lack of any gamma control makes the screen too black to see anything the instant the rain starts, which means if I'm not already at a safe zone by the time that happens, it's an automatic death.  Combined with the rain cycles feeling like it's just a pointless punishment against actually exploring and dealing with the world.  Just as I'm starting to feel like I'm making any kind of progress, I have to stop, turn around, and hope that I can stumble my way through black screens until I get into a safe area.

The first thing I did when I died due to being unable to see was quit out to the main menu and go into options and there are no gamma options to try to salvage this disaster.

And thus, purely because the game makes itself unplayable, I have to give it a solid "no".

146682795.review:
I love this game so much. It is probably the most frustrating experience I have gone through, but I still keep coming back. 
   Deaths seem unfair and unexpected because of all the randomness in how creatures spawn and behave, but that also means that the same section of map can play completely differently each time. The controls seem extremely slow and clunky at first, but as you learn the different moves you can perform, it becomes fluid and cohesive. There is a lot of difficulty in the game that many people might not enjoy, but if you can get past all that, the game is really fun.
   Now, I'm gonna be honest and say I did use the Rain World wiki. quite a bit. 
   For the first 5 hours or so I did play without any help, but I got stuck and had no idea what to do. While I do recommend figuring stuff out first, don't be afraid to use the wiki. There's no use ruining your enjoyment of the game just to have a "pure" run of the game.
   Overall, it's really fun even though sometimes it makes you want to chuck your controller at the screen and never play it again.

146479542.review:
In a world where the words "survival game" has become inundated with what seems like the same thing. Humanoid characters running around to progress through a tech tree and dominate the world around them, it is refreshing to see such a simplistic take on this genre.

You see, this game is not characterized by 'survival' because you have to obtain a certain amount of food to continue living, it is that in conjunction with the sheer oppressiveness of the environment around you that gives it it this genre tag.

You are prey, and you must act like it. Fighting is never the best course of action, it is always the last resort.

The only advantages you have over other creatures in this environment is your nimbleness. Your ability to hold tools and craft things is ironically outclassed by another species. You, a human, who have created technology to dominate your environment, are now lowered through this game to the place in the food chain as what is to humans is an ape, or monkey.

Rain World is possibly the most immersive non-humanoid survival game I have ever played, and it's not 3d.

Rain World's two dimensional playing field becomes less a restriction for the scope of the game and more an intentional design decision to make every room feel that much more claustrophobic. Each area is densely packed with all kinds of flora, fauna, and remnants of the old world, and its your job to navigate through all of it.

For this, you have been given ample tools, the nimble slugcat you control has access to an array of moves, all situated within a few simple button presses. Jumping, grabbing, moving, crawling, climbing, throwing and squeezing through pipes morph and combine into all sorts of movement tech that I couldn't possibly fit into a single review (seriously, watch a guide on it) however, the quick, snappy control scheme means that you only need those 7 basic things to get through the entire game. This game has almost no form of extrinsic progression, as the progression in your skill is reward in of itself. Whether you learn new movement tech that helps you make that one jump JUST out of your reach, or if you become that more in tune with your moveset, you'll quickly start to see you making fools of everything trying its hardest to catch you... Until you are caught being reckless.

The humbling nature of this world makes it satisfying to even hit the simplest of jumps, or best the comparatively tiniest of foes.
All that packed into great environmental storytelling and a grueling journey around all corners of the expansive and highly detailed map, that makes you sigh in relief when its over... and want to do it all over again. Hunter next, then maybe I'll get downpour and play gourmand, artificer... etc.

You might not be the strongest creature of the bunch, but you sure as hell are gonna triumph over and dominate this world as best you can.

146433494.review: I love it! While it can sometimes be difficult, it is very unique in a way that other games that seem at first similar can never come close. You could just play it as a normal platformer game, but you would miss out on the entire idea of the game, and it would eventually become impossible to move forward. You have to learn the traits of each type of creature. In fact, each individual creature has it's own personality. You can befriend a predatory lizards by bringing them food, but be careful. If you manage to take the mask off a vulture, the lizards other mid-range predators will fear you, but the maskless vulture will chase you down. If you see the scavengers raising their spears, you know they don't trust you, and if you are too aggressive to them, them might send some members out to kill you. If you grab a flying squidcada, you can jump higher. If you can't reach an area, throw a spear into the wall and climb on it. Don't let the garbage worm take your spear, though. Good luck!

146419974.review:
Wrote this coming off of my first play-though,

Rain world puts you in a situation where you are a lost little dude with no idea what/where the hell they are, hungry stomach, a world that you don't understand, and all you have to survive is a pile of debris and your wits.

This game is hands down the most refreshing game I've played in a long time. I don't think there is or will be another experience that is as lively, brutal, adventurous, mysterious, and amazing as this game. Went into this game mostly blind and, though it took quite a bit of time to get through this way, it was worth the journey. The replayability of this game is also amazing since there's many things to uncover you might have missed, plenty of slug cats to play as, and a fairly lively workshop and content community. 

I'd highly recommend everyone give this a shot, and even if it's not for you, it's a beautiful game that is unlike anything I've ever played. If you're like me and you've been thinking about it for a while but never really made up your mind on whether or not it'd be worth the time money and effort, go for it. It was absolutely worth every last minute and will be time and time again.

146409050.review:
I really try to enjoy this game, and im still gonna continue playing it, but at certain point it just feels like a chore

imagine if super meat boy had a maximum timer after wich you die no matter what, and every time you die you lose 20 minutes of progress, at many points in time that's how rainworld feels

the game is just counter intuitive, even when you're supposed to learn how to play with just watching, it's like they set rules and then made them not work 50% of the time

-this game requires patience to do most things, yet you can't take your time because you would either be being chased by a creature half of the time, or about to get killed by the ingame timer (wich is randomized each day, so you may just have to suck it up and waste another day idling before you have enough time to go trough) and if you instead try to rush, there will always be an enemy camping to the other side of the zone, wich you have to either waste time that you don't have to go trough, or risk it and do a 50/50 of dying and starting again or finally crossing

-this game wants you to learn, yet everything (item spawns, enemy spawns, enemy movement, and enemy AI) is randomized every day, you may get lucky and go trough a zone completelly unharmed, or have to deal with bad spawns, and waste another hour or so dying and respawning over and over, the game also punishes experimenting, since dying lowers you karma level, something crucial to go between each zone of the game

-the tools you have are there, but way too limited, you have 3 slots to hold stuff, in most zones one will be occupied to hold an item you need to traverse the zone, and if you are trying to discover the lore of the game so will be the 3rd one (wich mind you, discovering the lore involves an awfull ammount of backtracking) you may say this is expectable since one is doing a hard challenge put on themselves, but when i have to go trough three times the ammount of torture just to understand what's happening ingame i'd just skip the lore part and try to reach the ''ending'' of the game instead

besides that, you have the most useless map you could ever imagine, why would you divide it in three different parts? why would you make the player's experience harder in anything that isn't the main aspect of the game itself instead of what counts as one of their only tools? eventually i got so tired of dealing with it that i had to sink into the wiki (getting spoiled major things too, because lord forbbid you get to discover something yourself in the game about exploration without walking 10 hours) just to know where should i even go to begin with, the lack of context and the  minimal help of the overseer didn't get me too far last time (he's literally gone for half of the zones you traverse, cmon)

the game is just a slug (no pun intended, i love slugcats) and at more than one point it just feels sisyphean to jump from one savespot to another, i know that more than one will say this game IS meant to be hard and that im tilting madly, i know the game is fun but if there's no progress after four hours maybe others can enjoy it but i cannot

TLDR: sometimes, this feels like the complete opposite of a game with how it expects you to handle it

i have bought the base game and the downpour expansion, and i will probably keep playing it further until i get to finish it if possible, until then, my looks on the game are not good

and to whoever says skill issue, go back to your cbt session or whatever game you need to defend next

146384369.review:
A game that sacrifices everything for its world, so its good that the world is fantastic. Starts out bumpy and confusing but only gets better with time. DLC more than doubles the content for a fraction of the cost. The game has come far over its development and it shows with the later content.

While I recommend starting out vanilla be sure to check out the in game accessibility and mod options labeled Remix. If you want more, the workshop has many quality mods to help change the game to your liking or simply add more content.


A HUGE pitfall the game baits players into is to play Monk first. The game has reputation of being unforgiving, they're the 'first' character on the list, why wouldn't you want a "Significantly more peaceful one"? Because the developers are liars. Compared to Survivor selecting Monk considerably nerfs a number of your stats in ways that would not be immediately apparent to the player. You are forced into a flight-over-fight play style while the world itself STAYS JUST AS DANGEROUS if you were Survivor. Many enemies, environments, and obstacles simply can't be ran away from hurting the average player's starting experience as well as many techniques available to every other single character will not cut it as Monk. All the while setting you up for failure in future playthroughs when playing as the more combat based characters as Monk's campaign discourages you from fully learning all of your tools at your disposal. 

The trade off for Monk is that they take advantages the stealth and reputation system, systems that especially a new player would not be privy to unless they read the wiki beforehand. Even then every other character can also take advantage of said systems if abet at a slower rate (bar a specific DLC one). Ultimately you are hurting yourself for a drop in the bucket towards an optional play style choice. Monk is best saved for an post-DLC play through where you can access more optional content while you are already familiar with the systems in place.

146351027.review:
This game is clearly not for everyone. It is frustrating, harshfull, and can be a lot of bullsh*t sometimes. You are not in control of your environment, you don't know what you should do and where you should go. You have really few basics in the start and that is, now discover for yourself. 

But in the same time, this is the charm of this game. The difficulty is not insurmountable and you have to learn by yourself to master the controls of this huge ecosystem. The game is not overwhelming by a bunch of keypads and instead, it has really simple mechanics and more complex ones that you learn for doing certain movements or by doing some experiments. This is a great way to say "You have been rewarded" without giving you a load of stupid loots that you are not going to use anymay.

Also, the lore is amazing and you ask yourself question about what happen to this place while being submerged by brilliant and immersive panoramas with a feeling of emotion going through your veins. 

The DLC makes the game better by giving you more playable characters that have their own chronological period, taking place in the same environment in an different timeline and being different on how the world evolved before and what happen to it after, making certain region completly new (my favorite is when Drainage system becomes Undergrowth, making it more alive in the future instead of more "Sewers" in the past).

There is so much more to talk about this game but it will take too long to write down. 

I can understand that this game is really unfair mostly for new players like I was, but you should really give it a longer try to see how incredible it is. 
Play this game, you can have it for a really cheap price with Instant Gaming, as well for the DLC "Downpour".

146334826.review:
Rain World has the best AI I've seen so far in a video game and has an immersive and expansive world for you to explore. 

[b] Animations [/b]
Rain World has a unique 2D animation system. The game doesn't use sprites or pre-rendered animations - the animations are run in real-time by code and react dynamically to the environment and world around you.

[b] Survival [/b]
You play as a slugcat, a small creature low on the food chain, and are thrown into this dangerous world to survive. You must learn to use the environment to survive; by finding food and shelter, using the local fauna to help traverse the world, or learning how to out-manoeuvre the local predators.

[b] Movement [/b]
There is a lot of advanced movement tech in this game. Heck, there's an 87 page long google doc detailing how to perform most of this tech. Strangely, you don't need to learn any of it. It's all just there to enhance replay value and speedrunning.

[b] Adventure [/b]
The game is best experienced blind, there are a lot of wonderful things to find in Rain World; but if you are struggling to progress or understand what to do it may be worth looking up advice.

[b] Co-op [/b]
With the Downpour DLC, you have access to local co-op (which can be accessed through remote play), and 5 new DLC campaigns all of which have unique characters and changes across the world. Some criticise the DLC for being more game-like and less immersive, but I never ran into this as a problem.

[b] Achievements [/b]
Getting 100% achievements was ... in some parts a frustrating experience. Some of the challenges in the arena were a bit annoying (although some of them were great!). Challenge 70, while cool, was very annoying forcing you to replay the slow and boring phases 1-3 to access the much more difficult phases 4-6.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
Overall, I had a fantastic experience with this game. Highly recommended if you love exploring expansive immersive 2D worlds with a great artstyle and design.

I will preface the entire review that I did not get as far into the game as I would've liked, but I wanted to return it.
Rain World is absolutely gorgeous and mechanically amazing but with how punishing and grindy at times (if you're bad, which you will be if you just installed the game) I could not absolutely bear to play it more than 2 cycles at a time and did not enjoy more than a handful of minutes of my total playtime.
If you like incredibly punishing games with simple but very deep mechanics that are satisfying to learn and master, with stunningly good NPC AI and complex, interesting lore, you'll love it, but if you're not a part of the small ammount of people that would realistically enjoy the game you will absolutely loathe your time with it.
I don't recommend it to the majority of people, but I can see and understand where its fans are coming from.

146283409.review: I really thought I would enjoy this game, but it just wasn't doing anything for me. The map is confusing, many mechanics aren't explained (intentionally so, I'm sure, but still frustrating), hibernation locations (save spots) are seemingly arbitrarily laid out, enemies will one-shot you -- the final nail in the coffin for me was that even after almost two hours of gameplay and reaching an entirely different area (Industrial Complex) I still felt like I hadn't actually found anything interesting that was worth the exploration. I promise I'm not one of those people that NEEDS constant stimulation or something exploding spectacularly on-screen every couple minutes, but the lack of any kind of positive feedback for exploring just wasn't much fun -- it felt like all I would ever find were more enemies. Navigating through the rusty buildings is a good initial hook and quite beautiful, but the first couple hours of Rain World did nothing for me in terms of expanding on that hook or promising that there was something more beyond angry lizards in dilapidated areas. In fairness, it may get better later, but I'd rather refund it now before the 2hr mark and not take that chance.

A [b]chair[/b] is a piece of furniture with a raised surface used to sit on, commonly for use by one person. Chairs are most often supported by four legs and have a back; however, a chair can have three legs or could have a different shape. A chair without a back or arm rests is a [b]stool[/b], or when raised up, a bar stool. A chair with arms is an [b]armchair[/b] and with folding action and inclining footrest, a recliner. A permanently fixed chair in a train or theater is a [b]seat[/b] or, in an airplane, airline seat; when riding, it is a saddle and bicycle saddle, and for an automobile, a car seat or infant car seat. With wheels it is a wheelchair[14] and when hung from above, a swing. A chair for more than one person is a couch, sofa, settee, or "loveseat"; or a bench. A separate footrest for a chair is known as an ottoman, hassock or pouffe.

The chair is known for its antiquity and simplicity, although for many centuries it was an article of state and dignity rather than an article of ordinary use. "The chair" is still extensively used as the emblem of authority in the House of Commons in the United Kingdom and Canada, and in many other settings.

146252377.review:
In short: Artful and unique, Rain World combines procedural animation and compelling storytelling to give one of best platformers I've played. If you were drawn into the worlds of Ori and the Blind Forest, or Hollow Knight, you will definitely enjoy this one as well. To describe it in few words, it is dynamic and powerful in presentation. Very highly recommend.


At Length: This game hits a lot of marks, and while it does have some shortcomings, they're overshadowed by the things it does right.

What does it do right?

- Procedural animation. A technique full of technical challenges to implement, but done so fantastically in Rain World. Every creature in the game moves according to how it's able to, rather than a pre-set animation. Creatures can lunge, flap, lose their grip on surfaces, ect. This will also have an effect on your Slugcat's own movement.

- Environmental storytelling. Adventurous types will find plenty of ways to get lost, and along the way, see interesting sights and learn a little bit more about the world they inhabit. There are mysteries to uncover, but I won't spoil them here. 

- Music. James Primate and the rest of their team have created a soundtrack that not only supplements the environmental storytelling, but engages the player with the events on screen. The choice to make the music dynamic itself lends greatly to that effect. I often listen to the tracks while not playing. 

- Content rich DLC. Buy downpour with this game. It vastly expands the content of the original game in all aspects. More music, more areas to explore, more Slugcats, more lore. Do it. 

- Art and design. Rain World is a work of art in and of itself. There are places I needed to stop passing through and just soak in. There are moments when I felt overwhelmed. At some point I cried. In addition to evoking emotions though, I was also impressed by the range of designs of creatures and elements of the environment. Enjoy such classics like: bees that tie you down, and an insect half the size of a Toyota Corolla. 

- Skill and exploration are rewarded. The game is a journey, and not one just based on travel. You'll figure out what things means and how to use them, and it's a good feeling when you do. Knowledge and a practiced hand are king when it comes to survival. There's also cool little things to find throughout the world. Challenges and expedition mode add more levels of knowledge and skill testing.

- Local co-op. Not a feature I make use of personally, but I see the value it in for others. Support games that bring people together. Jolly cooperation makes cold nights in the shelters better for everyone. Online co-op is not an official feature, but one that's possible through Steam Remote Play. Since that's a direct connect feature, you might experience some lag when the person you're connecting to is far away. 

- Community. The Rain World community kicks ass. So many talented folks, kind folks, supportive folks. Some of those folks went on to put their love and hard work into the DLC. The community is active and positive. Join the Rain World discord, there you can talk about your journey through the game, see the art that's posted every day, discuss lore, why Saint is the best Slugcat, or talk about mods.

- Mods. In addition to an active community overall, there's also an active modding community. Turn a terrifying foe into a clown, add whole regions to your game, or find entirely new Slugcats with new looks and mechanics. Be sure to thank or support those good nerds that make the content. 

What does it not do right?

- The game is unfair. That's not me complaining, there are points where circumstances align to destroy your Slugcat in sudden and sometimes funny ways. But sometimes it's just out of your control. It's the nature of the game, being as dynamic as it is. This might be cause for frustration among some people, and unfortunately, it's not helped by what I'll mention in the next section. However, it's an important part of overall feel of the game. I'll let you discover why.

- Controls can be somewhat vague, and the immobile camera can cause lack of awareness beyond the edge of the screen. The controls for the game are simple, but there's a lot of different movements you can do. A series of buttons you press can mean something if you're standing on the ground, and something else when you are climbing a pipe. This usually isn't an issue until you're hanging over a pit. It's remedied with practice, calm input, or changing your settings. There are also audio cues that help with the camera issue. Additionally, quality of life mods exist for both of these issues.

To conclude: I cannot recommend this game enough. It's beautiful, there's cool game design elements to it, the story is evocative, the music invigorating. Creatures and places that firmly belong in our memory. A vast, mysterious, terrifying world to explore... and through it all, you. The humble Slugcat. Going WAWA and inconveniencing calculators. Only those folks who don't like platformers at all, or get incredibly frustrated easily, would I say your experience with the game could be hit or miss. But otherwise, buy it. Play it. Support it. Become Slugcat. Can you feel it? The spear in your little hands? Your body squirmshing through the pipe? The wag of your tail? The- no, get back... leave me... it's too late, I'm... the rains are coming... I must...  I... WAAAAAAAAAAA!

Oh, and you can hit Pebbles with a rock, 10/10.

146212776.review:
-Fascinating & unique creatures with advanced AI, that make up an entire living breathing ecosystem. You are not the center of the world but rather just another creature living in it. Creatures interact with each other and the environment regardless of whether you are there to see it. You can enter an area to find a fight already taking place, or a predator can grab you and be dragging you back to its den only for an apex predator to grab them and fly off with them. Everything is unscripted and happens organically, resulting in a world that feels unpredictable and truly alive.

-A very large and detailed world to explore, with tons of variation between areas and challenges that will test your abilities. The environment is absolutely gorgeous to look at feels overwhelmingly atmospheric at times. All of the areas have something to offer and are a joy to explore.

-A hauntingly beautiful narrative and rich lore in a fascinating world. This game has one of the most unique and interesting worlds I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. It feels truly alien and unknowable.

-Replayability in the form of multiple campaigns (even more with the DLC) that take you through an altered version of the world as a different character at a different point in the timeline, with their own goals.

-Amazing soundtrack

Be warned: this game is difficult. You are not at the top of the food chain. The world is cruel and unforgiving. But if you can get past that, or if you like a challenge, this game will deliver and incredible and unforgettable experience.

146201875.review:
This game is addicting. I lost my wife and kids to this. I lost my soul, I sold my house, I lost sweat and tears. I lost my friends because all I talk about is Rain World. My kids have stopped talking to me because I link everything they say to rain world. My child told me they have cancer and I said "rain world reference" and he immediately died. I got a severe drought warning on my phone and my children cried as I said "rain world reference." There will soon be a flood one day, and I know then, I just know, that my time will shine.

I tried to explain the lore to my children and one had an aneurysm, along with my fifth wife. The others have no recollection of that day, rain world reference included. 

I try to rid myself of this affliction, but the very act of ridding myself of the game draws me that much more into it, much like the ancients in their unending cycle of life and death. What a terrible fate I have found myself in, forever trapped in the cyclical nature of my own making, and forever alone in facing it. A drug that cannot be flushed out of the system. A system that acts like a drug. The game reflects on the unending of all things, and the madness that comes with the imprisonment of eternity. And I sit here, writing this, trapped in a hell of my own design, driven mad by the unending nature of my prison. I write, well aware that I will use these fingers to pluck upon the keys of my laptop once more, and perpetuate the cycle that brings me both ecstasy and madness in equal length. 

I miss my family. I miss my life. I bid my old ways adieu, and launch the game once more.

146198628.review: Awesome game. I'm not typically into this style of game but was well worth the challenge. Well designed platformer that places you into a diverse ecosystem with little direction, which is where my only problem lies. You can run in circles for hours not understanding where to go or what is next. I ran in circles, found key story points(that seemed to do nothing), went through the entire map for 30 hours before finding the only thing in the game to give clear directions(and activated some of the key points I found earlier). If you are playing for the first time I suggest exploring the world for a few hours before giving in but if you look up where to go, try to not be spoiled too much and take it a step at a time because a lot of the fun in the game comes from the shock and awe factor of exploration and finding new crazy areas and creatures.

146174225.review:
Rain World is the uncanny but perfect mix of your most intense fever dream and yout most delightful primal comfort fantasy, all wraped in tons of playable content. It's minimalistic yet complex; Brutal and cute; It's nostalgic, smooth and shiny, but still distopian and dirty; Welcoming and enchanting, but unbeliavably punishing to new players.

Basically, it evokes morbid games like Limbo and INSIDE, but gives you the chance to fight back and thrive; But make no mistake: The instant deaths and opressing atmosphere are still there.

The sooner you know your starting place, the quicker you can challenge the ones above you in the food chain.

And, of course, it is properly accompanied by a Dark Ambiance OST, complete with synth stuff and all.

Go play this game NOW.

146142776.review:
first off, Do Not Buy without a controller. The controls on keyboard are unresponsive at best, and flabbergasting at worst.
Usually in order for a 2d platformer to be fair, controls should be tight and it should be clear how you interact with objects. 
stuff such as the pipes that you have to crawl into, the items you throw, the branches you grapple, they're all a hat toss if what you want will even work. thrown objects can't be aimed and it's hard to tell if it's being thrown -x or +x. coming out of a pipe onto a grappled edge will sometimes just cause you to fall, needing to repeat an entire portion of the map. Multiple times. Pressing down in order to start a long jump will sometimes cause you to just walk off an edge instead. All this on top of having maybe 5 minutes between rain storms, having to collect 7 pieces of food with the horrible aiming (god forbid you think that the tiny dragonflies that light up and act like prey are prey), and being far away from a shelter trying to make the same jump 60 times because this time its chosing to grapple and climb onto the pipe you're trying to go into without your imput quickly made me decide to opt for a refund. 
I'm sure all this is smooth as butter with a controller, but I'd rather fight against monsters rather than whether I will be allowed to jump or it will just decide that I'm too close to a wall so I have to sit there grappled to it

This is a game you need to want to play to actually play it, it is a GREAT game and i personally love it however u will most likely wont enjoy it or play it for long if u personally genuinely are not interested in playing the game.
I do recommend the game if u WANT to play it, it is fab and the DLC is also super fun. The base game consists of three cats, one being easy mode (Monk), the base one (Survivor)  which i recommend playing unless u really have skill issue and then (i think) if u beat the game as either one u unlock one which is more speed run and survival based (Hunter). It took me personally 20h to beat Survivors campaign and it was really fun, i did resort to using a tutorial at some parts cause i felt mega stuck and i recommend u do the same if stuck but other than that just play the game, OR DONT PLAY IT AS U WANT! 
From there i tried the DLC adding 5 new slug cats with their own "Powers" quirks is if u will,
Gourmand, fat, can craft, can body slam enemies. Artificer, keeps getting hunted can EXPLODE!. Rivulet, super fast cat neat mobility but the RAIN comes sooner. Spearmaster, infinite spears, no mouth, eats with spears and Saint, Pacifist, long tongue and then God hood eventually.
I didnt beat all the campaigns yet but the one i did play are super fun loved them, i did however try all the slug cats and each one is unique (except Monk he is just easy mode) and great fun. The world is huge and the art style is stunning, really pretty and fun game.
Some downsides i do have to say is that the game can get u omega stuck and not soft lock but ur just lost u got no clue what u are doing, and thats normal i fixed that with a tutorial to get me back on track, and also the game is simply unfair sometimes lol and thats part of the charm but sometimes is SUCH bs.

Simply, only get the game if u are intrested and are willing to push through and play it otherwise dont bother cause u will not enjoy it. I do recommend the DLC but get it only after you have completed Survivors or Monks campaign. Very nice game.

145991844.review:
i love this game, however it is an abusive relationship.
the music and the art and the atmosphere are beautiful and the vibes are immaculate.
the ecosystem is complex and interesting and immersive and really feels alive.
the community is awesome and the dlc and mods add so much to the experience.
the story and worldbuilding is very interesting and it raises lots of questions, and the game will not give you the answers easily. you will not understand much at all on your first playthrough. it will take hundreds of hours of exploring every corner of this enormous world over many campaigns, and lots of curiosity and determination to piece together the story. (or look on the wiki if you just value your time)
the movement system is very complex but you must learn all of it on your own (or look up the nearly 100 page long document that documents it)

this game is an experience, but it is certainly not for everyone.
it is hard and extremely punishing. 
the tutorial teaches you only the bare minimum you need to survive and you have to work everything else out for yourself.
this game does not care for you. it does not value your time or your sanity. it will not forgive you for your mistakes. as one user has said, it does not hold your hand; it stomps on your fingers and watches them bleed. it is unfair. you will die. a lot. you will only progress through determination and strategy.
other than yellow, there is not much direction and you will often be lost.
as you progress through the game enemies will get stronger and more numerous and you will stay as weak as you started, so you must use the skills and experience you gained on your journey.
and all the challenge is worth it. the first time i reached the top of 'the wall' was the first time i have ever felt awe and when i finished the final campaign was the first time a game made me cry.
it was worth every moment.
this game is an amazing journey that you will never forget.

In all seriousness, Rain World may be my favorite game. It is brutally difficult, and that almost scared me away from playing it. The lore of this game, without spoiling anything, drives home how small and insignificant your player character is. Play Rain World if you desire to be lost in a world that will amaze all brave enough to explore it.

145867134.review:
This is a difficult review to write. Hundreds of hours in this game and yet I still feel hardly qualified to recommend it to another person. Don’t get me wrong, it’s an incredible game. More people should play it. Should you?

Perhaps.

I’ll start with the details. The pixel art looks incredible. The sound design is great. It’s rare to see the full potential of procedural animation realized, but Rain World does it. Every part of this world looks and feels alive. The excellent AI of the game’s various inhabitants contributes to that as well.

The gameplay is a more complicated topic. That’s not a cop-out way of saying the game isn’t fun to play – it is. But it’s also infuriating. Death comes for you easily and often unfairly. It’s not a roguelike, but if you can’t stand roguelikes I would hesitate to recommend this game to you.

The controls are in a similar situation. They’re not bad, and there’s an incredible depth of skill that can be achieved with them – once you’re done exploring this game on your own, check out the wiki’s movement guides. I’ve come to enjoy the controls, but only after a great deal of frustration.

This frustration is a core part of Rain World. You could not tell the story that the developer is trying to tell, could not provide the profound experience that Rain World does, without this frustration.

All the same, I’d recommend to everyone that they enable the “Remix” plugin on the “Classic” preset immediately. The quality-of-life changes this gives are invaluable, and don’t diminish the experience in any way. The other options can be tried on a case-by-case basis.

The Downpour DLC is absolutely worth it, and enabling the “More Slugcats” plugin that it grants you access to right out of the gate will provide worthwhile additional content in all your playthroughs. You should start with Survivor, the white slugcat, regardless.

If you can stick with it through to the end, Rain World will absolutely be worth the time you put into it. 9/10.

145775417.review:
Steam really needs to get out of the "Yes/no" binary ffs. MIXED review.

I really wish I could love this game, we have had lot of wonderful memories together. The art, the music, the memories~ 

But them I remember that every day it beats the piss out of me with its bare knuckles. 

Review at 22 hours in, still on my first run though this is normal from what I see. 

This isn't a hard because its challenging, though it has it's moments. what it is truly; is a creators vision not aligning with game design foundations. It's a GREAT vision, and although I've cut my life expectancy in half from the blood pressure, I love the good that's in this game. The issue stands that there are some serious game design faux pas embedded in the bones of this. Extreme punishment for failure, poor signposting (not talking about yellow), crucial mechanics are not explained. Crucify me if you like for this, but it's also a wiki game; just because something *can* be discovered in the game, doesn't mean it *will* be.

If the goal was to create an immersive experience around being a powerless part of nature; frustration is the enemy of immersion. There are ways to punish and reward the player for engaging with your creation that don't cause them to be frustrated and "switch-off". Instead, it chooses to "reward" you with an opportunity to experience the game for longer than 15 minutes without giving your head another contusion.

I will finish this game, and I plan to finish all the other stories as well; but it is a violently abusive relationship, and i can't in good conscience recommend anyone attempt to *play* this.

Watch an experienced play through, preferably without commentary. Or turn on all the remix mods to say "fuck you" to the devs for designing the default experience around the highest levels of play. 

I love this game for what it does right, great experience, great art, design, soundtrack. Terrible game play.

****
EDIT
****
I just completed the survivors story and, now I can only push my last point harder. This game would have been far more enjoyable had I not gone in blind. 

There were no answers in the core gameplay, you won't get your questions resolved. You have to extend your gameplay out across multiple characters or ludicrous fetch-quests, at which point the "Big moments" turn from being amazing spectacles and strong resolutions of a characters plot to:

"...OH thaaaats what was happening, huh I guess that's neat"

Would have been nice to know the significance while it was happening, but eh.

145632583.review: an absolute gem of a game. The graphics, though simplistic, are pact full of feeling. over time you will develop a connection to the game that cannot be found anywhere else. the world and creatures are incredibly complex, and seem alive in a way I cant explain. i've never really liked fully single-player games, but this is a beautiful exception. If you are thinking about watching tutorials or play throughs first. don't. trust me, just get the game and learn it on your own. initially nothing is intuitive, or explained, but every problem can be solved in a few minutes with just a little thought and learning. half of the fun is learning to live in such a foreign place. get the game, don't watch tutorials, and thank me later.

145605976.review:
I actually have only played this game with friends. My experience with it has been both infuriating and amazing at the same time. I would definitely recommend playing with someone who has experience if you do, as its a hell of a lot easier to learn everything with guidance. My first playthrough I was both literally and figuratively carried through about 65% of the game, and now I get to be the one to carry someone else through it.

10/10 would definitely recommend
